author: andrew@makevisible.com
body: Hey Zamp, just reaching out with a quick question around sales tax tracking for a specific B2B transaction. Currently, all of our sales are direct-to-consumer via Stripe (which, of course, integrates seamlessly with you). For a particular B2B deal, we'll be selling 150 devices and memberships in bulk to a Californian university, who will then distribute them to staff and students. We're currently at 60% of the $500k CA threshold, and this transaction would take us up to 80%, so no issues around tax collection, we're more looking for guidance on how best to handle the threshold tracking in this case. A couple of options we were considering: Manually import the transaction into Zamp via CSV, alongside our regular Stripe-collected transactions. Preferred. We can raise an invoice outside of Stripe. Raise a manual invoice in Stripe and have Zamp handle tax collection as you do with our usual B2C sales. Slightly cautious with this, as reporting may be impacted (and also individual tax thresholds - see below) due to the way our Stripe is currently set up. In addition, we plan to activate the memberships via 100% discount in Stripe for each of the 150 users, but unsure if this may create tax threshold implications on a per-user basis - could you comment on this? Be good to get your input. Thanks in advance! Andrew Long Financial Controller

author: jason@shopravella.com
body:
Hi Chris and Ashley,

NEW ISSUE IDENTIFIED -- please hold off on approvals/processing.

New issue:
When we do an EDIT ORDER (eg a size change from XS to S), we know already that we need to manually minus out the 'duplicate' item - since only 1 item was shipped.
However, it seems if the shipped item ends up getting returned for refund anyway, Zamp is NOT recording the tax adjustment for that returned item.

Example order: Only 1 item ordered -- price $195. Only 1 item paid. Size changed from XS to S/4 (via Edit Order). See 3 line items in Zamp calculation below: Because of the edit order, Zamp currently thinks 2 items were sold, for a total of $390 with $34.14 in tax. There seems to be a manual deduction (I think by Chris) that deducts the 1 duplicate item, resulting in -$16.27 in tax. However, after the item actually shipped (S/4 size in this example), and the customer decides to return for refund, we should get a negative tax adjustment of lets say $16.27 or $17-- but that's missing now. Chris -- please have a look at this example, and we can discuss today before 5:30pm EST if you have time.

We are out of the office on Thursday and Friday, so would need to review today.

And then once we find the logic issue here, let's pls go back and search for and adjust for all similar cases (Edit Order + Refund afterwards).

Thanks,
Jason

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bobbi and Jason, Following up quickly here with a few updates! First, we're happy to share that our engineering team has released some significant improvements since mid-June that now properly account for these transaction scenarios with Shopify transactions: Voided/Expired transactions - we now create a separate refund transaction to account for these. I validated this by reviewing voided orders within a Shopify export and comparing them to Zamp. Partial refunds that are not order edits are captured, and I validated this by reviewing 'partially_refunded' orders within a Shopify export and comparing them against Zamp. The above means that I made adjustments to Shopify Transactions within Zamp by reviewing 'partially_paid' and 'paid' transactions from a 'web' source with a positive outstanding balance. Please note that the process we previously agreed upon remains unchanged, except for the updates mentioned above regarding voided/expired/partial refund adjustments. We also have additional work scheduled to start in August 2025 to reattempt finding a solution for order edits within Shopify. Meaning‚Äîthere's a chance these adjustments won't be necessary in the future, but we don't yet have an exact timeline. I've also adjusted for the remaining prior period refunds in California and Colorado. I've attached three files: A file showing the Shopify adjustment transaction work. An export of the Zamp Transactions for states with filings this month. This includes a Pivot table showing tax amounts by state. The tax-due estimate I sent previously is also included in this file. The prior period refunds brought into June 2025 for the previous periods. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Scott, Thanks for your patience here! Although I don't currently have a transaction-by-transaction tax rate file to share, I've identified the cause of the difference in tax due expectations here. Regarding Pennsylvania: We found that for PA, just the state rate (6%) was collected on some of the transactions, which did not include any locals (there are two in PA), and this ties into some details that Matt Grattan shared on 7/10/25 around ensuring not to overcharge customers when rates change throughout the state, and over time. Once we recalculated the PA Transactions to match Zamp's expectations, the tax-due estimate was updated to a number closer to your expectation. The estimated tax-due amount is now: $4,291.38 . This includes a timely filing discount of $43.35. Regarding Texas: Texas is a bit of a tricky situation, which we share more details about here , with Business-to-Business Software as a Service (B2B SaaS) because our understanding and Zamp's calculation engine considers the below information, which differs from a flat 8.25% rate across the board: Texas considers SaaS a data processing service, which subjects it to an 80% sales tax on the service's price. This also means that 20% of the price of a SaaS service in Texas is considered tax-exempt. The above leads to the following amounts and breakdown, which align with the tax-due estimate for TX: A taxable sales amount of $7,810 - these are sales to non-exempt entities. The original non-exempt total sales amount (excluding non-profit sales) was $9,762.78 , which the taxable amount noted above represents as 80% of. A tax-due estimate of $644.33 , less a timely filing discount of $3.22 , for a total estimated tax due of $641.11 . The above means that the $ 641.11 tax-due amount is our estimate of the correct amount, considering the taxability of SaaS in Texas. A question and next steps: Do we have your approval to move forward with filings for both Texas and Pennsylvania? These two states have due dates of the 20th this month, and we want to ensure timely filing. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chuck, Renee, and Beth, You're welcome; thanks so much for your patience here. I believe we have everything sorted out for the current filings due this month in California and Washington. We'll work on documenting this process internally to ensure this is accounted for accurately and smoothly from now on. A few items to note: 1) We cleared out all of the transactions in Zamp and recreated the transactions utilizing the reports Renee shared, and the custom Zamp invoice list report. 2) We imported California Transactions and did not import any Washington Transactions because the sales tax liability for WA showed a negative balance (see the attached file.) This is something we can help address in future WA sales tax filings, to recover overpaid tax. 3) I sent an updated tax-due estimate to Chuck and Renee. When accounting for sales tax rounding (which CA requires, at the jurisdiction-level), the estimate is within $3.36. A few questions: 1) Urgent ‚Äîdo we have your approval to proceed with the sales tax filings in WA and CA for Q2 2025? Our filing team can file these on time, but the faster we can proceed with approval, the better. 2) Regarding invoices in non-nexus states or states where tax is not yet collected, and this might be a question for Beth or Renee: This will help us ensure that we accurately determine if Forcible Entry has crossed an economic nexus threshold in states other than Washington or California. The reports Renee shared are sales-tax-focused and likely won't work for states without tax collection (yet). Could we utilize the Zamp Sales Tax Report (which is a 'Invoice List' custom report) and follow the steps below, in the interest of maintaining consistency with cash-based accounting? Or, is there a better report to use so we can view all invoice payments in any state other than California or Washington?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Renee's answers: Questions: 2) Does the above approach and plan work for you? I am not a report export, but as long as they are charging the correct taxes for each customer, the amount¬†is correct. 3) How long might clients make partial payments for? Is there a set period or limit of any kind? This is not something I can answer. While most customers pay in full, not all do but the sales tax collected for a payment, whether in full or partial, is captured on the report. 4) Are there any transaction types in QuickBooks Online that we should also include in Zamp other than Credit Memos and Invoices? I have no idea. I don't do the invoicing but this sounds logical. 5) Outside of the above approach, would it be acceptable to utilize the invoice list report for any states where Forcible Entry does not yet have nexus and isn't collecting sales tax? I don't know who they should be charging taxes to or not, but I created other ones for the states I show they owe money to in Quickbooks. You will need to change the date for the time period you file each time. Chuck would need to tell you what other states they are doing business in that they do not collect taxes for. I hope someone there is helping them with the tax settings in Quickbooks so they are charging clients correctly.

author: renee@bizisblooming.com
body:
Hello!

This report does show the amount of sales tax collected. The report has been saved and shared, but you still need to make sure you are capturing the correct time period. Right now it is for April-Jun 2025. Questions: 2) Does the above approach and plan work for you? I am not a report export, but as long as they are charging the correct taxes for each customer, the amount is correct. 3) How long might clients make partial payments for? Is there a set period or limit of any kind? This is not something I can answer. While most customers pay in full, not all do but the sales tax collected for a payment, whether in full or partial, is captured on the report. 4) Are there any transaction types in QuickBooks Online that we should also include in Zamp other than Credit Memos and Invoices? I have no idea. I don't do the invoicing but this sounds logical. 5) Outside of the above approach, would it be acceptable to utilize the invoice list report for any states where Forcible Entry does not yet have nexus and isn't collecting sales tax? I don't know who they should be charging taxes to or not, but I created other ones for the states I show they owe money to in Quickbooks. You will need to change the date for the time period you file each time. Chuck would need to tell you what other states they are doing business in that they do not collect taxes for. I hope someone there is helping them with the tax settings in Quickbooks so they are charging clients correctly. The goal here would be to avoid creating separate transactions within Zamp for the partial payments associated with these transactions. Doing the above could artificially inflate the economic nexus threshold counts because some states have both an "order count" threshold and a dollar threshold. Thank you!

Renee

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Renee, Thank you for your response and willingness to collaborate on figuring this out! I hope that your time out of the office is enjoyable or what it needs to be. We're more than happy to work through questions that come up here over email. After further discussion and review on our end, this is the plan we've come up with to sort this out for filings this month and most likely, in the future as well: We can run the custom invoice list report we built here , covering the period from January 1, 2024, to the present. I've also attached this export. Then, cross-reference the invoice list report with the invoice numbers from the report you shared (which I believe is this report). We'll utilize the address data from the invoice list report and the amounts from your report to capture all the necessary information. Questions: 1) Is there a saved version of the "Forcible+Entry,+Inc_Transaction+Report" that could be added to the 'Custom Reports' section within QuickBooks Online or shared with us in some way? We aim to access this report without requiring you or Chuck to take any action, but we would like to use this report as the source of truth for the amounts. 2) Does the above approach and plan work for you? 3) How long might clients make partial payments for? Is there a set period or limit of any kind? 4) Are there any transaction types in QuickBooks Online that we should also include in Zamp other than Credit Memos and Invoices? 5) Outside of the above approach, would it be acceptable to utilize the invoice list report for any states where Forcible Entry does not yet have nexus and isn't collecting sales tax? The goal here would be to avoid creating separate transactions within Zamp for the partial payments associated with these transactions. Doing the above could artificially inflate the economic nexus threshold counts because some states have both an "order count" threshold and a dollar threshold.

body: Hello! I am out of the office a lot next week and not working. Please email the exact questions you have and I will try to answer them. I know what Quickbooks shows as received payments are always correct and matched properly to invoices. You created a report based on $0 balances for receivables and as I told Zamp before, that won't be accurate. Clients pay partial payments, sometimes they pay invoices from a year prior. I am not a Quickbooks report expert, but I will definitely try to help as much as I can and know about:) Thanks! Renee

Please use this link to schedule a call or share your availability, and we can send a calendar invite.

The issues we've found are: The CA liability reports do not match the invoice exports, regardless of whether we filter for a $0 balance or not ($0 balance is supposed to be a cash-basis account). This likely isn't an issue with how amounts, invoices, balances, etc, are handled by accounting folks. We believe this is a display or logic issue with QBO itself. We need to: Determine the source of this issue, which is likely to be within QuickBooks Online. Determine how to proceed with the filings. We're past the internal filing deadlines, but CA is a later-in-the-month state, so we could get this sorted out before filing and still file on time.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Chris, Thanks for sharing this! I didn't know that shipping was taxable in Texas. Is labor? No worries! The taxability of shipping varies from state to state, and in all kinds of scenarios; we're here to help with that. Labor may or may not be taxable depending on the kind of service involved. What types of services would you be referring to? We have a few that might fit this kind of category, but this may also be something to run by our Tax Research team for confirmation. These are the categories we currently support: The " TPP " below refers to " Tangible Personal Property ", which is generally taxable products. Regarding the PDF you shared and CCF_000129: I reviewed this further and also triple-checked some items within your Zamp account for your Texas sales tax registration. I found that when Zamp registered Accelerated Tooling LLC in Texas, we registered you with a 'Single Local Tax Rate' license type in that state. This is similar to other simplified sales tax rate licenses and programs in different states, and it's typically used by out-of-state businesses. The Single Local Tax Rate for Texas with this type of sales tax registration is 8% on all transactions, regardless of the shipping address. For this order and considering shipping taxable, $3.36 would be 8% of $42.00 . This means that a single sales tax rate is collected on orders shipping to customers within Texas, and here are some resources about this: Under ' How to Collect Sales Tax on Interstate Texas Sales ' in our Texas Sales Tax Guide, here . On the TX Comptroller's page here . I hope this helps, and please let us know if we can assist with anything!

author: ap@torqstorm.com

body: Hi Chris, Thanks for letting us know about this; we'll help sort this out. After reviewing the tax calculation logs on our end associated with the WooCommerce store here, I'm seeing a few different Tax Due amounts returned by our API for this zip code on 7/4/25 Within Zamp's API logs, I can see 6 calculations with a subtotal of $24 and $0 shipping cost. Then, I also see a final sales tax calculation with a subtotal of $24 and a $18 shipping cost. I'd like to see how the order looks on your end because Zamp would consider shipping to be taxable in Texas, and that might be the cause of the difference here. A few questions: 1) Was this order placed on 7/4/25? 3) Could you also please share a screenshot of the order from within WooCommerce with me? Regarding your question: Please advise as to how this is being fixed. Should we be able to trust this software? Of course! Once we confirm the situation and the taxability of the order, we'll be able to help determine what, if anything, needs to be fixed. Yes‚Äîyou should be able to trust the software, and we're here to help answer questions and ensure any items are resolved.

author: caroline@zamp.com
body: Hi Tech Success, I'm reaching out on behalf of our customer Todd, who is currently experiencing an issue with their eBay integration. eBay is routing all jewelry authentication orders to a centralized address in California, which is causing a reporting issue. These sales are being attributed to California and artificially triggering nexus, even though the end customer address is located elsewhere and they have not actually met nexus thresholds in CA. Could you please advise on the best path forward to ensure the customer‚Äôs shipping address‚Äîrather than eBay‚Äôs California authentication address‚Äîis used for nexus determination? Specifically: Is it possible to adjust the mapping within the eBay integration to reflect the actual customer address? If not, would you recommend the customer use CSV uploads instead to ensure accurate reporting? Is there any other workaround available that allows us to continue using the eBay integration while resolving this? Appreciate your help in looking into this! Thank you, Caroline

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Hi Chris, I hope you are doing well! I just got back and I think there has been a bit of a misunderstanding - the B2B transactions need to be recalculated as well with Zamp. This is because we collect on the state portion only for B2B and eat the rest of the cost so we can't rely on the tax collected field for B2B either. We'll need to update the returns to reflect this. Can we chat sometime this week to set an action plan for fixing this? Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, You're welcome! That sounds like a good plan to me, and we'll have until mid-next week to move the filings along in the process. A quick note: We recalculated the tax for the B2C sales because tax was already collected on all of the B2B sales within your nexus states. After fixing a bit of detail with the currency conversion (utilizing a conversion rate of 1.37), the amount due is lower, but there is now an amount owing for Iowa. On our end, we show tax being calculated as out of pocket for LumiQ, which is: $113.52 in Ohio. $69.86 in Iowa. Have a wonderful weekend and enjoy your OOO time!

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Sounds good thank you for the update Chris! I will try my best to look at it but if I don't get to it this week Erica will be doing the review. As long as we're reasonably close to our internal calculations then we are comfortable! Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, You're welcome! That makes sense, and we'll talk internally to improve these situations moving forward! We'll have an updated tax-due estimate heading your way within the next 1-1.5 hours. We're just triple-checking some currency conversion items for the QBO Invoices that were imported. If you'd like to hop on a call to discuss, please use this link .

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Hi Chris, Thank you for looking into it! Yeah I do think now that the source of confusion is that we told the onboarding team this - but there must have been some crossed wires during implementation/support. Basically, we don't collect sales tax on the CSV upload (B2C) transactions because it's so small and we eat the cost. We also don't collect LOST on the QBO (B2B) transactions since it's smaller so we agreed with the onboarding team to recalculate everything based on the ZIP code. Let me know if that makes sense as we're happy to jump on a call! Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, Thanks for letting us know! This is interesting to hear, and there might have been some misunderstanding from past conversations. We'll get to work on this tonight and tomorrow, and follow up with any questions or updates. We should be able to make the change and have an updated tax-due estimate your way tomorrow.

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Hi Lucas, Thanks for sending this over! To be honest, these returns don't look right (they are too low). The reason is because Zamp is pulling the Sales Tax Collected field but we have been very open from the start that we are not collecting on certain components of sales tax and eating the cost ourselves. The expectation is that Zamp will recalculate the sales tax to be remitted on each transaction based on the invoiced amount. Happy to jump on a call today or tomorrow to fix as I am OOO next week. Can someone on the team look into this ASAP? Thank you, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, Thanks so much for your patience here! We have been investigating this and are a bit stumped. When we export orders from BigCommerce and compare them to Zamp, we find amounts that vary from what you shared and from what Zamp has as the tax-due estimate for this month (June 2025 and Q2 2025 filings). That said, and because Dorm Company has a Florida filing, we're right up against an internal deadline (end of the day today, 7/16) to ensure that Florida and other states are filed on time. A few questions: 1) Would it be OK with you if we proceed with filings as they are this month, with the tax-due estimated and listed on the 7/7/25 email? This will enable us to ensure timely filing and also provide additional time for review and troubleshooting. Then, if we find the cause, we can account for the difference in future filing periods (e.g., July 2025 filed in August, or Q3 2025 filed in October). 2) When you have a moment, could you please share any files, supporting work, or links to the review you (or your team) did of the tax amounts that were collected? This can help us compare further, and we should be able to find the root cause. One way or another, we'll get this sorted out. Please let me know if you have any thoughts or questions regarding the above.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Taylor, You're welcome, and thanks for sharing these totals with us! To confirm, were those totals based on a combination of the transactions and data from within BigCommerce? Are there any other sources? Everything should be through BigCommerce or Square, as Amazon collects and remits as a Marketplace Facilitator. The Square transactions that we see from June were from TN and TX. There are some timely filing discounts included in our estimates, but they aren't large enough to account for these variances. I definitely see what you're referring to with the amounts being low. We'll investigate this further on Monday, while comparing it to BigCommerce data. Just to be safe, the total for tax collected for California for Q2 (which I believe is April 1st - June 30th, correct me if I'm wrong) was $7,571.13. Does California need to be rechecked? This is interesting to hear, as CA should likely also have a larger amount. Here are some details for CA's Q2 2025 filing, as Zamp's tax-due estimates now fully account for the quarterly prepayments made in CA: 1st Prepayment - $2,073.00 2nd Prepayment - $1,748.00 Total Prepayments - $3,821.00 We see a total tax collected in CA of $5,757.00 , which is lower than your estimate. We have a few methods and scripts for comparing data within Zamp to BigCommerce; we'll follow up with any findings. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Gavin, Thanks for sharing this data and these details with us! that I should still be including these sales on the report you, and Yes‚Äîwe would still want to include these transactions on the report sent to us. That said, we (Zamp) would need to know which specific transactions are ones that occurred through the Shop sales channel within Shopify; there are a few ways to determine this: In the Shopify United States Sales Tax Report, these transactions are categorized under the "Filed by Channel" category, as Shopify shares here . In an order export from Shopify, the "Channel" is noted as "Shop". Then, within Zamp, we would treat these transactions as marketplace transactions with a designation of "SHOPIFY" to ensure tax is not remitted twice. Do you have any Shopify channel-related details being funneled into the system, through which these reports are built? we are not paying sales tax twice This could be the case, but I'm unable to know for sure, as the data provided to Zamp doesn't indicate if the transaction occurred through the Shop channel or not. Do you see any SHOP channel transactions in any of the data provided since 1/1/25? If you'd like to schedule a meeting to discuss this further, please use this link . We want to ensure data accuracy here and collaborate on the best path forward.

body: Hello Grace, Thanks for your patience with this! We looked into this further, and we've confirmed that we see the following California prepayment amounts within your CA CDTFA account: Prepayment 1 - $13,517.14 Prepayment 2 - $16,714.24 The tax-due estimate sent earlier this month did not account for those prepayment amounts; however, our filing team will take these into account when filing the return. The above means that the amount Zamp would estimate to be filed would be closer to $21,395.62 after subtracting those prepayments. Please note that, since New York follows a fiscal quarter (e.g., Q2 is June 2025 through August 2025), Zamp's tax-due estimate for NY would be considered the first prepayment associated with the NY Q2 2025 sales tax filing. A few questions: 1) Considering the above, do we have your approval to proceed with ETERNE's filings this month? 2) Regarding NY‚Äîif you'd like us to confirm the prepayment and filing amounts for this state, could you please reset or update your NY password and share it with us? We were unable to log in due to an expired password here. The password could be shared securely using this one-time secret tool.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, You're welcome; thank you for the follow-up. Please could you also confirm receipt of the request to switch the Shopify Zamp connection back to the live Zamp account this Friday ? Yes‚Äîwe will switch the Shopify Zamp connection back the production Zamp account and I've set a reminder on my end to ensure this is completed tomorrow morning (7/11/25.) Please can you confirm orders look correct in Zamp? Yes‚Äîthe orders look correct within Zamp. After further investigation and comparison, I found that the order count difference was due to: Shopify does not create separate refund Transactions (it's noted within the order), but Zamp does create separate refund and order transactions. This happens because Zamp utilizes a ledger-based accounting approach, which creates a clear line of separation between orders and refunds. Some orders were not synced to the Zamp Sandbox account because they had order dates before the initial sync range (in April 2025); the initial sync was 5/1/25 and forward. After resyncing transactions, the order count totals match, when accounting for separate refunds. And also confirm the UK time window you'll be switching the Shopify connection to your live instance? Sure! What UK time window would be best for you all here? I usually start my day around 9 AM EST (1 PM UK time), but we can also target  a later time up to 11 PM EST (4 AM UK time) if that's better. Otherwise we can check with the broader team to see if anyone has a different availability. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Briana, Thanks for sharing these details! I looked into this further, and you're right, the amounts are close. Most of the differences appear to be related to the following items: Timely filing discounts in each state. Our tax-due estimates automatically account for these. For CO, this discount is $93.96 For SC, this discount is $11.72. Rounding NC appears to fall into this category, and possibly time zones as well. Time zone differences between Stripe and Zamp: Zamp would file using EST in NC and SC. We'll file using MST in CO. We see these kinds of differences commonly with Shopify, but similar logic would apply to Stripe, depending on the time zone used in Stripe's reports/views. So that you know, these differences are expected and compliant. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Thanks for reaching out! Could you please clarify the documentation you requested regarding returns in Shopify? We would only need documentation if a partial refund for a customer located in a nexus state (Texas) were processed in Shopify for June 2025 or Q2 2025 for either Metal Mark or Dandy Lion. Sure! We would just need a CSV file containing refund transactions that match the attached template and guidance in this article , for partial refund transactions. The minimum necessary details for us to import the data into Zamp are: An Order ID. The date the partial refund was processed. The subtotal amount. Any shipping amount refunded. Any tax refunded. The Ship To Zip code (the full address is best, but a zip code is the minimum) I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: ok perfect thanks for confirming!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks for sharing this context! I understand, and this context is super helpful. I'll share some details below that I believe will help ensure we're on the same page. :) I want to make sure that whichever way we do it Zamp is calculating the correct tax amount that has been collected ans should be remitted. Agreed! I want to confirm this as well. The good news here is that Zamp's Shopify integration has logic in place that can look for either handling of US sales taxes: Tax exclusive - tax listed separately. Tax inclusive - tax included in the product price. As if the system assumes we are including it in the price in the USA, but we are now adding it to the price, then the system may be calculating the wrong numbers To my understanding and review, Zamp will be able to detect whether the Shopify transaction has tax included in the price, or if it's now added to the price (separately). Meaning‚Äîour system's calculations will differ, depending on whether Shopify tells us how the tax is included in the price or not. Our Shopify integration (system) will handle both situations and calculate correctly from there. As i understand it in both cases Shopify itemises the tax collected out into a line in the order so would assume the system should just be looking at this "tax total" line? Yes‚Äîwe do look at the 'tax total' line, and we also look for a property the Shopify API provides us with called taxesIncluded , and our integration handles it from there (Based on if this is 'true' or 'false'). I hope this helps!

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi Chris, Historical we have included VAT in all our pricing, including in the USA. This changed a few weeks ago (around the start of July) so now we add tax on top of the price, but just in the USA. I want to make sure that whichever way we do it Zamp is calculating the correct tax amount that has been collected ans should be remitted. As if the system assumes we are including it in the price in the USA, but we are now adding it to the price, then the system may be calculating the wrong numbers As i understand it in both cases Shopify itemises the tax collected out into a line in the order so would assume the system should just be looking at this "tax total" line? Thanks Edley

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks for the response! Isn't this the wrong approach? Could you please share more about why this might be the wrong approach here? I just want to ensure we're on the same page, as I may have misunderstood when you noted the following. We recently updated our settings on the 26th June so that tax is now charged at checkout instead of included from the order total. When I review your Zamp account's transactions from April 1, 2025, to June 25, 2025, I see that Zamp is bucketing transactions with tax collected across various date ranges and states. My understanding is that the tax was included in the cost of items sold. I also see tax collected from June 26, 2025, to June 30, 2025. After reviewing the code related to our Shopify integration, I found that we support tax-inclusive pricing (included in the item's cost), which was introduced late last year. That said, it is correct that the best and most compliant approach is to list sales tax separately (also known as tax-exclusive pricing, where the tax is not included in the item's cost). This compliance piece focuses more on complying with sales tax regulations than on reporting and filing. We'll continue to hold Drool Arts filings this month as we discuss this further. However, please keep in mind that we need to have the various state filings moving along in the process by the end of the day tomorrow (7/16/25) to ensure timely filing.

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi Chris, Isn't this the wrong approach? We've switched from including tax in US to adding tax at checkout

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Edley, Thanks so much for your continued patience here! We've looked into this and confirmed that Zamp is accounting for tax-inclusive pricing here. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Eddy, Thanks for letting us know! Yes‚Äîwe'll investigate this and follow up as soon as we're able (likely early next week).

author: edley@drool-art.com
body: Hi there, We recently updated our settings on the 26th June so that tax is now charged at checkout instead of included from the order total. Could you check this feeds through properly to your reporting? Thanks Edley

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tammy, Thanks for the context here! We can fast-track the investigation here, considering the critical meeting on Monday, as we'd like to ensure we handle this in the way that best helps you. Regarding Pennsylvania: The tax-due estimate for Pennsylvania is $201.23, which includes a timely filing discount in PA. Here's the breakdown: We see a total tax collected of $203.32. There is a timely filing discount in PA of $2.03. The remainder of the difference ($0.06) appears related to rounding within the sales tax logic; these slight differences can happen due to the nature of sales tax. Regarding Michigan: Within Zamp, I found that $137.59 in tax was collected for customers located in Michigan.. The reason Zamp is noting that $1.40 is due is due to two reasons: There is a timely filing discount in MI of $2.80 (the full tax due Zamp calculated is $4.20 .) Within Zamp, our system is designed to view digital products (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS) as tax-exempt in Michigan, which means we'd expect $0 tax to be collected on those transactions. This means that we see $133.39 of the $137.59 tax collected as over-collection. We have the option here to ask our filing team to file the $137.59 amount instead of the $1.40 (less any timely filing discounts). Then, later this month, we could schedule a meeting or discuss via email to determine why more tax was collected than Zamp would expect. Would you like me to ask our filing team to file the $137.59, less any timely filing discounts, in MI? Please let us know if you have any questions!

body: We can go ahead and file MI. I have a financial meeting on Monday and can't wait until next week. Your team can go ahead and file the rest. We will take care of MI today. thanks tammy

I've also attached a copy of our latest plugin version. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Kate, Thanks so much for your patience here! I've shared answers to your questions below. Please let us know if this helps! 1) The CA amount ($379.29) aligns with the taxes collected in June, but Q2 should be much higher? Yes‚Äîthe amount Zamp estimates will be remitted to the state (paid/due) should align with the June 2025 tax collected amounts, and this is what we see occur with clients who California has assigned a quarterly Prepay filing frequency. This happens because our tax-due estimate already accounts for the prepayments made for Otteroo in CA: 1st Prepayment - $459.00 2nd Prepayment - $458.00 Total Prepayments - $917.00 2) Is WA is higher than what I see in shopify due to B&O tax? Yes‚Äîthis should be due to the B&O tax in Washington, as that amount is $21.90 for Q2 2025. 3) Maryland in Shopify (for all of 2024) is about $130 higher than what I see on zamp Just so you know, part of this difference is likely due to a timely filing discount of $5.42; however, this only accounts for a portion of the discrepancy. Overall, this difference is likely due to the date range associated with the MD filing frequency assigned to Otteroo by the MD Department of Revenue, which is a Fiscal Annual filing frequency that covers the period from July 1, 2024, to June 30, 2025. When you have a moment, could you please confirm the following items with us to help with this investigation? The date range associated with the MD Transaction review in Shopify. A screenshot or copy of an export from Shopify for MD is being used to compare here. We'll also hold Otteroo's filings until we have approval to proceed, due to the questions here, as we want to ensure timely and accurate filing. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, Another follow-up here! We've made the necessary updates to adjust by an amount close to what you noted and shared in the Shopify vs Zamp comparison file. The overall adjustment we made was -$2,700.53 because the majority of the Washington Q2 2025 difference was due to WA's Business & Occupation tax (B&O), which is a gross receipts tax, not collected from customers. We include this amount in our tax-due estimate. The B&O Tax amount for Q2 2025 was $518.80 , while the difference you noted was $690.03. This means that we adjusted WA by $171.23. We're sending an updated tax-due estimate along with an increased review window time, within the next few minutes. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Marjorie, Thanks for the follow-up and your continued patience. We should have an update about this today, or Monday (7/14) at the very latest. We're keeping an eye on the state filing due dates, and we'll help ensure filings are processed on time.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Marjorie, Thanks for the response! We can certainly understand your perspective, and we would like to partner with you to resolve this situation. A slight difference, such as 1.25% (even if the dollar amount seems high), is very likely related to time zone differences between Zamp and Shopify. Zamp's tax-due estimate and filings will use the US time zone that aligns with the state's capital, meaning we use EST, CST, MST, PST, Hawaiian Time, and Alaskan Time across the various states. We'll dive into this further and confirm if the difference is related to time zones. If that's the case, our recommendation would be against adjusting by this amount, as it would mean not remitting tax to the various states. If time zones aren't the cause, we'll find the root cause and work with you to adjust the data accordingly. We should have more details to share or questions by early next week. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - Normally, we'd try to push back on this. However, we can conduct a quick comparison using the Zampboni tools that Lucas built to confirm whether the issue is related to time zone differences or something similar. If that's the case, then we can provide a quick explanation. If it's not, and we can determine the root cause, we can adjust. I'll hold their filings here. https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/38934726/card_tables/cards/8813898594

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for the response here! If I delete this transaction now, will it be adjusted correctly next month? Sure! If you delete the transaction now, we can manually import a refund version of this transaction to account for it. Ultimately, the transaction could be left as it is so that the original data used to file for Virginia remains intact. Then, when we manually create the refund for this transaction, we can note on the line item description that this is a refund because the transaction was canceled, never shipped, and refunded. Does the above work well for you here? The 4 day window provided (truly 3 with the holiday) is really tight. Is there any way to expand that? We appreciate your feedback and understand your perspective. We'll share this with the broader team and consider any possibilities. The tricky portion of these situations is that the state filing due dates (each state's deadlines) don't change to account for holidays, and Zamp's filing timeframe and approval windows are designed to ensure we file timely for all Zamp customers, while optimizing for efficiency across teams.

body: Hi Monica, Thanks again for being so patient here! I'm following up to note that we were able to account for the below invoices that were voided/refunded: SS15179 SS15730 That said, there is a larger population of voided invoices that we're unable to account for due to low or $0 tax collected in the state(s) associated with the transaction. The reason for this is that Zamp is unable to file negative amounts in any state or any state's local jurisdiction. We're currently developing a plan to move forward and track the remaining voided transactions in future filing periods. I'll also share a list with you so that we're all on the same page. We will also be following up about some duplicate transactions in our other email thread (with the subject "Re: Incorrect NY filing"). For now, we will be sending out the tax-due estimate to ensure timely filing, as Florida is due on the 20th, but has some complex rules regarding payment submission. However, Florida will be $0 for SnapStream this month.

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Chris, Attached are the five Gamefound transactions for June which were previously reported in May, but now in June have new shipping and tax amounts, and a new street address. (There are no entirely new Gamefound transactions for June, but make sure you saw the new BackerKit transactions on the previous email which are new June transactions.) My thought is that we should therefore show 10 June transactions, 5 which are reversals/credits of the original May transactions, and 5 of which are the "rebilled" transactions. Do you need me to add the 5 reversals to this spreadsheet as well, or is the 5 transactions in their "new form" enough? Or alternatively, do you have any thoughts on a better way to handle these? Sean

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Chris, Just about done... So as I said, there are two pieces to this for June. First, the final wave from the old BackerKit for Minnesota sales. That's the easy part - attached in a spreadsheet. Second, the Gamefound. I expected that once I finished my transforms, which cross-reference the current state of the Gamefound data against what we have recognized as sales to date, I would show no new activity in June. I was right, except for five anomalous transactions that are showing me weird numbers. Investigating these, the best I can tell, these are orders that had to get redirected to an updated address at the last second, after we'd already given our warehouse the go-ahead to ship (and recognized the sale). The new address means the tax rate changed in Gamefound's system, and there's now additional sales tax on the orders from what there was when we previously reported them in May. But it also means we reported the sale in May to a state that is not the state where we got the product to in the end. And Gamefound's data doesn't make this clean for us - they don't give us a reverse sale in the original state and a new sale in the new state. They just make the edit and show us the final version. That's the problem with Gamefound reporting - anything new that happens to an order just changes the order, regardless of the date of the order, so it looks like the order has been that way since the beginning. There's no concept of a period closing or a change order to a transaction, just an unauditable edit. It doesn't even show you what the original ship-to state was - we have to cross-reference that in our data. The way these crowdfunding sites work means there's always going to be some weird error like this that creeps in and we won't report things like sales tax perfectly. Anyway, for these five transactions, on our end, I suppose the cleanest thing we can do is try to show a reverse sale at the original address and a new sale in the new address. I will get you the info on these five shortly...

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks for letting us know.

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Nick, I should have this June data for you within the next few days. There will be two spreadsheets, which, when ready, I will upload to the shared Google drive previously provided: The first will be BackerKit data for Minnesota . This will possibly be the final batch of BackerKit data ever, unless we end up returning to BackerKit one day. The second will potentially be a new batch of Gamefound data for all states . However, it's possible this one will turn out to be $0 for June once I complete all the transforms. Sean

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick - This one is strange! I checked a few customer QBO accounts (billboards, LumiQ, Forcible Entry), and those accounts still have options like the ones below with the addresses that we need: Shipping Address Ship To Billing Address Bill To We accomplish this through a custom report in QBO, typically based on the invoice list report that he mentioned. Additionally, it doesn't appear to be a QBO-wide change from a quick review, but rather an issue specific to their account. They may need to contact QuickBooks (Intuit) support by following the steps in this Intuit article . The report we usually use: The columns: This article shares some details about adding columns like this to a report, but as far as I can tell, it should be the same process they used: https://quickbooks.intuit.com/learn-support/en-us/help-article/customize-reports/create-custom-reports-quickbooks-online-advanced/L1LHo5Ti2_US_en_US Maybe we can ask him to add integrations@zamp.com as an accountant user in QBO? What do you think?

author: jeff@ampedbikes.com
body: Hi Nick, It looks like quickbooks online changed their accessible columns on the invoice list report where billing address and shipping address are no longer options to include. There is a column "Bill To" on the CSV that I've included that includes the shipping address with zip codes included. This is the only option that I've found on the invoice list report that enables us to include those details. Do you have any other recommendations on pulling from quickbooks?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick - Is this one you could investigate some this week? The filing card is here: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/38934726/card_tables/cards/8814077616 Account: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm3oqxyo500vz99dr0gvlj30y It appears I forgot to move it to hold/recon, as per the Zapier history here , and there is no note on the card. We should be okay, but we want to verify. Review their QBO transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm3oqxyo500vz99dr0gvlj30y/transactions?connectionId=cm3yrp31p000203mle0yfhzm0&date=2025-01-01~2025-07-22 . There are 16 in total, but it's a high dollar amount. Compare against Shopify to see if any have the identical amounts, addresses (probably zip code), or any pattern that seems to stick out: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm3oqxyo500vz99dr0gvlj30y/transactions?connectionId=cm3yrp0oo000103ml04ecebdc&date=2025-01-01~2025-07-22 We could probably filter this further to look at states where they had QBO transactions (there are only 16 in there this year). If we can't find anything quickly, we'll likely want to ask them to add us as an accountant user in QBO, because our integration with QBO isn't currently designed to exclude invoices by Shopify order number in the PO number field, or to determine if they're from Shopify. They'd add: integrations@zamp.com This shares how to do it: https://quickbooks.intuit.com/learn-support/en-us/help-article/account-management/managing-accountant-users-quickbooks-online/L2AcdYvHw_US_en_US

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Initial thoughts on the filing card here: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/38934726/card_tables/cards/8814077616 We might be able to disconnect QBO. The Shopify QBO tax-exempt transactions will likely be grossed-down this month since they'd have $0 tax (most likely) but could duplicate gross sales in the future, now that they're using the tax-exempt/wholesale settings.

author: glee@ysebeauty.com
body: Hi Amelia, We will use both platforms. We use Shopify to process B2B orders, but the actual invoices will be issued and get paid via QBO (This is also where the amount is the most accurate). So that's the reason why we want to exclude all the B2B orders from Shopify. In QB, when I issue an invoice, I note the Shopify order # in the PO number field, example below. So you can match the invoice in QB to the order in Shopify. Thank you, Grace Lee (Controller) - 562-477-9280 Julie Tran (Accounting Assistant) - 562-955-0530 PLEASE COPY OUR ACCOUNTING EMAIL: ACCOUNTING@YSEBEAUTY.COM FOR INVOICES.

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: Hi Grace, We will review your Q2 transactions to check for duplicates. Are you planning to move all of your wholesale business to Shopify and discontinue using QB? Thank you,

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: @chris or @nick - Can one of you jump in here? Looks like we may have some Shopify duplicates. I am confirming if they're moving all of their b2b sales to Shopify but for this month, we may need to work out the duplicates.

author: glee@ysebeauty.com
body:
Hi Amelia,

Per your instructions, I changed the tax collection settings for B2B customers to tax-exempt.

However, when you file our sales tax for Q2 2025, can you please help make sure the following customers will be excluded from Shopify sales because the sales are already included in Quickbooks (and I believe Zamp is still pulling our QB data for Wholesale sales). Tamella Cassis Beth Willis Knockout Beauty: buyer@knockoutbeauty.com Thank you,

Grace Lee (Controller) - 562-477-9280
Julie Tran (Accounting Assistant) - 562-955-0530 PLEASE COPY OUR ACCOUNTING EMAIL: ACCOUNTING@YSEBEAUTY.COM FOR INVOICES.

author: amelia@zamp.com
body: Hi Grace, B2B orders or wholesale orders where no tax was collected will still be included on your returns. You can either use Shopify's dedicated wholesale features , or you can designate individual customers as tax-exempt. Here is more information on how to do so. Please let us know if you need more assistance on ensuring your wholesale orders are marked correctly when Zamp pulls them in. We can hop on a quick call with our technical support team to review if needed. Thank you,

author: glee@ysebeauty.com
body: Hello, As we integrate B2B orders into Shopify Online Store, going forward when you file sales tax, can you please exclude all orders with tag "B2B"? Thank you, Grace Lee (Controller) - 562-477-9280 Julie Tran (Accounting Assistant) - 562-955-0530 PLEASE COPY OUR ACCOUNTING EMAIL: ACCOUNTING@YSEBEAUTY.COM FOR INVOICES.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thank you for your response and the additional details. 1) Great! I'm glad to hear this was resolved. The situation with the rates returned here was related to what happened with Colorado. Overall, Colorado, South Dakota, and Indiana were affected. 2) Noted regarding the usage of the Google address autocomplete here, as that would certainly explain the difference between the two addresses and zip codes. We highly recommend Smarty, and I'd forgotten that it was already implemented on your end (from our earlier call). 3) Perfect! At the time of my initial response, I was unaware of the underlying reason for the behavior we were seeing, and my initial guesses were incorrect. I also see the taxes object included in the API request with either the 46241-55 74 or 46241-55 34 zip codes. We should be all set here now. If anything else comes up or you have any questions, please let us know.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: For tomorrow: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/42435159/card_tables/cards/8810286319#__recording_8810923853 Justin's response in the escalation above notes that Indiana was affected by the issue that affected Colorado. So, it's likely working now due to that. Eng is going to put some other items in place to test and check these situations better. I'll word that a bit differently with the customer.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Josh and Team, Thanks a ton for your patience here! Our Engineering Team investigated and resolved the situation with Colorado here last night. What happened here was an unexpected edge case (which had not occurred in the past) when our teams were loading updated tax rate data as a part of one of the quarterly tax data updates. Our teams are also working to implement additional testing and processes to prevent this from happening in the future. Now, we are seeing the full rate returned for an address after triple-checking via internal tools and our API. Here are some screenshots noting this: The tax rates noted above also match the Colorado Sales Tax Lookup Tool here : Please note that Zamp's tax rates will align with the CO's General Merchandise (Tangible Personal Property) rates, as listed in the Sales Tax Lookup Tool. The 'General Merchandise - Use Tax' rates are tied to consumer use tax rates (for individual consumers or businesses ), instead of sales tax. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

Will the shipping portion of the sales tax in these situations be refunded to the customers? Just so you know, the tax would need to be refunded to customers to remain compliant with California, as sales tax must either be remitted to the state or refunded to customers.

author: hanna@thewayo.com
body: Hi Chris, Is there any update for this issue? Sincerely, Hanna

author: hanna@thewayo.com
body: Hi Chris, Thank you for the clarification. We would like to request a "refund" for the California sales tax prior to early June using the following approaches: Could you assist with refiling the 2025-Q2 California sales tax to ensure that shipping charges are treated as tax-exempt? This would help us avoid both issuing a refund and paying unnecessary tax on shipping. Do you have any recommended method for claiming a refund on the 2025-Q1 California sales tax charged on shipping, given that shipping should be treated as tax-exempt? Sincerely, Hanna

author: hanna@thewayo.com
body: Add Qiling and Mandy in the loop.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thank you for the question and your patience. According to California tax regulations, should sales tax on Shipping & Handling charges be collected before early June? No‚Äîto our understanding , Shipping itself or Shipping & Handling when combined (not stated separately) is generally considered tax-exempt within California; this includes before early June 2025. Specifically, do we need to refund the Shipping & Handling tax for orders delivered to California prior to the beginning of June? Ultimately, the decision here is up to you (or the business). The taxes need to either be remitted to the state or refunded to the customer. If you decide to refund the tax on shipping to customers, please let us know, and we'll make sure it is accounted for in future sales tax filings processed for California. I'm noting this as we've seen businesses decide to handle this in many different ways, partly because processing refunds for every customer in scenarios like this is not always an easy undertaking. If you'd like to schedule a call with me and TheWayo's account manager, please let me know, and we'll share a link (after this upcoming US holiday). Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: hanna@thewayo.com
body: Hi Chris, According to California tax regulations, should sales tax on Shipping & Handling charges be collected before early June? Specifically, do we need to refund the Shipping & Handling tax for orders delivered to California prior to the beginning of June? Sincerely Hanna

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for your continued patience here! It's July 1st, and a busy time on our side. After further investigation and review of internal situations associated with this discrepancy, we found that the difference in tax calculated was due to an improvement needed within Zamp regarding the taxability of Shipping & Handling in California. Our Engineering and Tax Research teams released the improvement to fix this, towards the beginning of June. Earlier in June 2025, and some cases before that month, Zamp was calculating tax on shipping for customers located in California. The above means that the Zamp API tax calculation response on June 30, 2025, is the correct and most up-to-date, accurate calculation. This also means that Shipping & Handling will be treated as tax-exempt by the Zamp API at this time. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Hanna, Thanks for sharing those examples with us! I believe we've found what happened here, and we're confirming some of the details. I'll have an update to share with you tomorrow morning (7/1/25).

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Looked over this with @lucas - the difference here is related to previously treating shipping as taxable (via the API) for California vs not. Related linear tickets: An issue Ryan raised ~1mo ago: https://linear.app/zamptax/issue/TBD-379/shipping-incorrectly-taxed-in-california-via-api-calculations The tax research fix: https://linear.app/zamptax/issue/TAX-2856/ca-shipping-rule-updates In the request examples, the difference was always SHIPPING_HANDLING for the item taxes/rates. On 6/9 we treated it as taxable, and on 6/30 we did not; it should be exempt.

The good news here is that we recently, and internally, released a significant API logging improvement as of June 25, 2025, so we shouldn't need API request/response examples from that date forward. 2) Also, are there any more recent examples of this discrepancy? I'll also review our logs to find examples of this behavior, but the answers to the questions above will help expedite the process.

body: Hello! As I am reviewing the numbers for Chuck. I still have concerns. Just for California, in April I showed $9,493.71 was due based on taxes charged and collected as they are Cash Basis, not accrual as per the balance sheet. You made a tax payment of $2428. In May, there was another $3,547.25 tax collected bringing the current total balance of $13040.96 due, for the remainder of April and May taxes collected. Your recent report shows just over $11.2k due for May alone. When Zamp was hired, part of the agreement I believed was making sure Quickbooks was charging and collecting taxes appropriately and everything was flowing properly. There are taxes on the books for other states, so are those being incorrectly charged or not being filed/paid? Bloom originally invited Zamp to be an accountant user in February 2025. This invitation was not accepted and another was sent yesterday which was accepted. Something is still not right which leads me to believe the taxes on invoices are perhaps not correct? Please follow up with Chuck and verify with him that the correct taxes are being charged and collected. Your reports should always match (maybe off a few pennies) what the balance sheet shows. As he receives payments in Quickbooks, it allocates the portion to sales and tax based on his invoices. Thank you! -- Renee Lindsey Director of Client Services, Bloom Accounting Solutions Phone: (480) 734-5088

author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Hi Chris, Sounds good all around, thanks. We'll continue with the monthly exports and look forward to truing up the numbers during the next filing period. Best, Aksel G√ºng√∂r Hi Askel, You're welcome! Great! We'll bring these transactions forward into the July 2025 filing period(s) next week, and one of us will follow up once that has been completed. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Yes‚Äîthe monthly reports across all states will be sufficient, and we will not need a separate and additional quarterly or semi-annual export of orders for any of those states. This way, we're all consistently on the same page, and it ensures we have all the data across all states, regardless of nexus status or filing schedule. I hope this helps! How would you rate my reply? Great <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/1/> Okay <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/2/> Not Good <https://secure.helpscout.net/satisfaction/799310422/record/9112329457/3/> -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> {#HS:2969188151-146357#} Hi Chris, Thanks for the quick response. *Question‚ÄîAre you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 > filing period* Yes, it sounds like that's the best approach for both the May transactions and the late June transactions that didn't make the cut for this most recent filing period. *Question‚ÄîDoes that work for you and make sense in this context?* Yes. Just to clarify, will the monthly reports across all states be enough or will you also need us to send a separate and additional quarterly/semi-annual export of orders for those respective states on non-monthly filing schedules? Best, Aksel G√ºng√∂r Hi Askel, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team jumping in! Thank you for the follow-up and for providing this data. *1)* OK, noted, and this makes sense to us. *2)* Normally, we would be able to include these additional orders in the tax calculations for the most recent reporting cycle, with filings due this month, July 2025. As of today (7/7/25), Ficks Music's sales tax filings, due this month, have been released. We didn't hear back before the deadline noted in the email, Thursday, 7/3/25, which was sent out on 7/1/25. - Meaning‚Äîthe sales tax filings are already being processed and are in varying stages of submission to the various US states. We could handle this in a similar way to how we'd recommend handling the May 2025 transactions. *Question*‚ÄîAre you OK with us including these transactions in the July 2025 filing period *3)* For the May 2025 transactions, we can include them along with the June 2025 transactions in the reporting and filing period processed for July 2025 in August 2025. *4)* Yes, that works for us! We recommend including all July 2025 transactions across all states, as this can help ensure that transactions from states that are filed quarterly or semi-annually are not missed. *Question*‚ÄîDoes that work for you and make sense in this context? -- Chris Ralph support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> Hi Nick, As a follow-up to the thread below, attached are the exported orders for the following period: *January 1 - June 30* 1. You'll notice in the spreadsheet that there are now duplicate lines for refunded orders/line items. The original order line items are in green, the refunded line items are highlighted in red. These should cancel each other out. 2. Could these orders be uploaded/added for sales tax calculations on your end for the most recent reporting cycle (June / quarterly / semi-annual)? Could we then receive the typical email report with updated tax liability figures for each state? 3. How would we go about adjusting for the previous month of May? The sum is going to be pretty small ($0.88 + $1.16 of tax across 2 orders). 4. Starting next month, the spreadsheet we send over will only have July orders, does that work for you? Will we need to send a separate spreadsheet at the end of each quarter / semi-annually to cover those reporting cycles as well? Thanks, Aksel Hi Aksel, Apologies for the confusion, you are correct in the tax being $80.47. I was mistaken and re-did the import with the refunds as additional rows. Normally for a refund we would have an additional row with the same transaction ID with a following -1, -2, etc and negative values to offset the initial transaction. This is the process you would need to adhere to for the following CSV files sent to us. I appreciate your diligence and patience, and I am happy to try and answer any other questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. For this example, I removed the repeated the line item transactions and summed the transaction tax total which we use, not the line item tax amount. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel wrote: Hi Aksel, Thank you for your patience with this. *For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this* *compare to your MI estimate?* - I am seeing the same tax amount of $33.65 for MI on my end from Jan 22 - June 17. *Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state* - I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. *Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. * - If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. - In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions. -- Nick Kondak support@zamp.com P: (866) 438-9267 [image: Zamp%20Customer%20Referral%20Email%20Header.png] <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdeAmX5uuBIu03wbmUGsWebsgLa-hyD_YKj-tmItm1o6pYAIA/viewform> Hi Nick, Thanks for looking into the file. To clarify, that total will be broken down per state for reporting purposes to reflect new totals for each state, correct? For instance, I'm seeing MI = $33.65 in the file. How does this compare to your MI estimate? Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state (ideally with tax rate % listed for each)? I understand that it's unlikely for state-specific totals to be off when the overall tax total matches but it could happen and perhaps more importantly, we want to make sure our calculated estimates upfront are as close to correct as possible on a state by state level. One last thing to point out - we were a bit late in getting all of this going/organized so the file I sent over includes orders over several months. Just bringing this up because I know reporting per state varies (monthly, quarterly, semi-annually, etc.). I also noticed there were 2 transactions that were in the returns in the > refunded column (AL), which I wasn't sure if you wanted to be included. The > tax totals with the returns factored in were both *$73.46*. When we cancel/refund a transaction, the sales tax is included in the refund so it seems to me like excluding those amounts is correct for reporting purposes, right? If so, we wouldn't want to count those. That said: - wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. No need to 2x the $3.70 and $3.31 since they're not listed twice in the list. - when we send you the file, we can filter the list so that credit memos/refunds are removed, would that lead to less errors potentially? author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Hi Nick, - If order # SO1100000219 in row 19 was a regular order (not a refunded one) then the tax amount would be $7.01 - This would mean that the total, overall tax amount would be $87.48 across all orders on the spreadsheet - Since order # SO1100000219 was cancelled and refunded, it's as if it never happened, and so we can simulate this by simply removing that order from the spreadsheet. In doing so, the total sales tax number becomes $80.47 (or the original $87.48 minus the $7.01). The spreadsheet you sent over lists the total amount as $73.46, effectively double counting the $7.01 amount. Could you explain the logic behind the tax amount of $7.01 being a negative number and not simply 0'ed out by the refund we issued on our end when we cancelled the order? Thanks, Aksel

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Aksel, The state totals I sent over was an export from our system. I attached a filtered CSV from the original file you sent over showing the tax total. author: aksel@ficksmusic.com
body: Hi Nick, Thanks for the follow-up. Just to clarify a couple of points: I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state Are the per-state totals you sent over coming from your system and calculations or simply a filtered list from the export I had sent over? If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return > ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that > and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be > good to include in future transactions list sent to us. I think order-level information is being conflated here with item-level information: - The order in question had 2 items in it, thus the two rows for order # SO1100000219 - Column AB lists the total tax paid for the order, thus the column header "Order tax". The total tax paid on the order was $7.01 - Column CZ has item-level tax amounts of $3.70 and $3.31 (or $7.01 total for the whole order), these represent the amounts paid per the 2 items in the order So, shouldn't the total amount of tax be the sum of all the item-level tax amounts in CZ ($87.48) minus the two items from order # SO1100000219 ($3.70 and $3.31) which were refunded, for a total of $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31 = $80.47? Why would $7.01 be subtracted twice if it were paid once by the customer? Thanks, Aksel

author: nkondak@zamp.com

Do you have a breakdown and similar totals comparison of what was calculated in the file vs. your rooftop-specific estimates per state I have attached a CSV with the breakdown for each state. I don't have a top-down report for every state and tax rates, as they vary within different counties. Wouldn't the new total be *$80.47*? I got there with $87.48 - $3.70 - $3.31. If you remove the return out of the total it is $80.47, but then the return ($7.01 we use the transaction amount) in column AB is subtracted from that and that equals $73.46. In regard to the refunds, we do import those for calculations and would be good to include in future transactions list sent to us. Please let me know if you have any further questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, Thanks for letting us know about this! That being said, rather than adjusting that prior liability to zero now, will it work to leave that as a liability debit on the books for now, and offset our June report for Minnesota with a $395.28 credit? In this situation, we should be able to account for it in the June 2025 filing period for Minnesota as long as there is enough tax collected to cover the $395.28 amount. The reason for that is that the various states do not allow negative local jurisdiction balances on their filings. After briefly reviewing the MN Q2 2025 data, we may be able to account for this credit, depending on the amount of sales bucketed into Ramsey County, MN, once it's time to file that return. Currently, the sales volume in this county is $2,763, with a tax of $14. Otherwise, the transaction would need to be moved forward until it can be accounted for. I can investigate this further by Tuesday and will follow up with the results or any additional findings. What is the best way to approach these adjustments? What do you need from me to report voided invoices? I believe we'd want a credit memo created in QuickBooks Online, referencing the invoice that was voided by it, for this purpose. If we want to track it there, we can create one. Alternatively, we can adjust within Zamp once we've validated that there is enough sales tax in the associated local jurisdiction.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Persha and Jen, Thanks for your patience here! As discussed during our call on Friday, we confirmed that the timezone issue didn't affect the 2022-2024 historical data that was imported in February 2025; it was also recalculated for overdue filings in April 2025. We also reviewed the following months for Connecticut and found the causes noted below. The June 2025 CT tax-due estimate was higher due to a timezone issue. There were 23 CT Transactions with $11.53 in tax collected that were moved into June, in addition to the June 2025 transactions. The June file had $163.26 in tax collection. The combined total was $174.80 , which becomes $175.00 when applying Connecticut's rounding rules for their filings. The May 2025 tax-due estimate and tax remitted were lower due to the timezone issue. This amount was $156.75 in tax collected, which becomes $164.00 when applying CT's rounding rules for their filings. The April 2025 does appear to have been affected by the timezone issue. We're currently working on the January through April 2025 data to determine if and which transactions were also affected by this timezone issue. Once we've confirmed this, we'll update the data, share the results, and ensure that any transactions in states where Q2 2025 filings were already processed are moved forward, as we did with the May 2025 transactions. I've attached two files: a June XLSX file with tax totals by state and another XLSX file showing the May 2025 transactions that were moved into June 2025. This will help us all ensure we're on the same page. Please let us know if you have any questions!

Transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm34x4f5o01qn14lgi27uxuk8/transactions?date=2025-06-01~2025-06-30&shipToState=CT June file had $163.26 in "transaction revenue" transactions with tax. For May 2025, the difference was due to transactions that had a timestamp/timezone, and we moved those forward into June - the difference is exactly $11.53 For April 2025, the transactions matched, but the report didn't update until after we refreshed it (something was "stuck" in the tax calc process.)
