author: chris@zamp.com
body: Here's an updated, filtered XLSX file based on what Lucas shared; it's filtered to transactions placed in April due to the timestamp issue. The differences are definitely due to Zamp's timezone adjustments when a timestamp is included in an import file. Ideally, we could just bring the May 2025 transactions bucketed into April 2025 (4/30) into June. We'll need to update our process for Sauce to convert to short date and ensure that the time and timezone pieces aren't copied over. I'll follow up with them.

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: @chris I've identified that discrepancies in May‚Äôs tax and sales reports are linked to how transaction dates are processed. Transaction dates in the customer file are recorded at midnight (e.g., 28/05/2025 00:00:00). Our system currently converts these to the previous day (D-1), causing transactions from May 1 to be reported in April. This leads to small tax and sales differences in May reports. This does not appear to be a timezone conversion issue. If the issue is on our side , we could: Adjust Our Process: Update our import logic to convert timestamps to short dates before importing into the admin system, ensuring transactions are reported on the correct date. Alternatively, request that the customer send transaction dates as short dates (without time) in the CSV file. Escalate to the engineering team If this is simply a timezone misunderstanding , we could communicate the current logic to the customer for clarity. Data attached

author: chris@zamp.com
body: We still need to investigate why there's a difference between the amounts the customer noted in their 6/14/25 reply above ( here , which includes a comparison between the notice sent on 6/11) and the file(s) they shared in this ticket. The Basecamp filing card is here: The liability report they're referencing: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clxc36ayb00wu5g1ot2kuqn8t/customer-reports/liability?monthRange=2025-05~2025-05 The differences are likely small, but we'll want to: Review the source files and sum various amounts (either with an existing script or Pivot Table). Compare that against what we filed, the liability report, and the notice. It's possible items were still processing when we sent the notice, but that should be unlikely. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hey @lucas @nick - I'm tagging you here to share an example of an API-related question we might receive. In this case, Zamp is automatically recalculating transactions created via the API. This was the default and only option for a while. Now, we support disabling this with a recalculate property, but we want to be cautious about recommending it, as it could easily be abused. We can use the Variance Reviewing Metabase query to troubleshoot situations like this and look for: A positive or negative taxDue amount where the taxCollected amount is 0. No exemption, tax code, etc, is listed. Here's an export filtered to the transactions causing this: I deleted a few columns. Eventually, I'd like to put together something more concise, query-wise.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Mandy, Thanks for checking in and your continued patience! Yes! We investigated this further and found that additional tax was remitted because Zamp files based on the tax that we'd expect to be collected when our API is used, and there was $0 tax collected on two transactions. Those two transactions were: CS-2156-0225 on 4/28/25. Zamp did not receive a tax code , customer-based entity exemption , or a purpose exemption (e.g., RESALE). CS-1437-2580 also on 4/28/25. Zamp did not receive a tax code , customer-based entity exemption , or a purpose exemption (e.g., RESALE). A few questions: 1) Do we know why the tax wasn't collected here, and a reason for not collecting the tax wasn't sent to Zamp when the transaction was created? 2) If you have any logs available from April 28, 2025, could you please share the API request and response associated with these transactions?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for your patience here! We looked into this further and confirmed that the majority of the Connecticut tax-due estimate difference was related to missing the in-person Shopify POS Transactions. I also believe we've found the cause of this, and I'll share more details below. The other variances appear to be due to rounding, timely filing discounts (where Zamp's estimate is lower), and potentially time zone differences. We've manually imported those transactions for this month, and here's an updated tax-due estimate: State code Period Estimated sales tax AR May 2025 $57.00 CT May 2025 $1,080.00 GA May 2025 $244.31 IL May 2025 $622.00 KY May 2025 $119.07 MD May 2025 $191.41 MA May 2025 $545.89 MI May 2025 $290.93 NE May 2025 $56.70 NC May 2025 $498.03 OH May 2025 $511.97 RI May 2025 $47.14 UT May 2025 $69.81 VT May 2025 $81.03 VA May 2025 $266.49 WV May 2025 $55.25 Combined Total: $4,737.03 Question ‚Äîdo we now have your approval to proceed with Select Seeds' filings this month? We aim to have these moving along by the end of today, but we can hold them a bit, until the end of the day on Monday (6/16/25). The goal here is to ensure timely filing by the states' due dates. The cause of this: This issue occurred because the Zamp Shopify integration's access to your Shopify store is missing the " read_location " permission, a newer requirement that Shopify recently introduced. Specifically, it allows us to view the POS locations and associate those addresses with the transactions in Zamp. This permission can be added by going to: Settings ‚Äî> Apps and sales channels ‚Äî> click "Develop Apps" (in the top right) ‚Äî> Zamp ‚Äî> Configuration within your Shopify Admin. Then, click the "Edit" button next to "Admin API integration." Search for "locations" and add " read_locations " by checking the box. Click the black "Save" button. This was an item we reviewed in all Zamp customers' Shopify stores, but it was missed because there weren't POS Location sales for us to import from Select Seeds until May 2025. I'm also happy to hop on a cal l to walk through the above. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for sharing those details! This is interesting because we should pull in Shopify POS sales, but it could be related to Zamp's permissions within your Shopify store or some other configuration item. I'll dig into this further and let you know what we find!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello Kay, Thanks for your patience here! We have calculated sales tax on the price and use tax on the cost of goods. I do not see where these values are broken down on the CSV, so I am unsure where / how to enter. In this situation, the sales tax would be placed in the transactionTax column within the CSV template. At this time, Zamp does not currently support importing transactions with business use tax on the cost of goods, as Zamp's product and services are geared towards sales and use tax collected from customers. If you're referring to sales and use tax (some states call "sales tax" a form of "use tax" for out-of-state businesses), then it would belong in the transactionTax column as well (combined with sales tax). I've connected with Caroline about the business use tax piece, and this is something that could be discussed further. However, if there was an installation charge or other charge, should this also be included in the total or broken out? Yes‚Äîif there is a charge for a service or product that is tax-exempt or potentially taxed differently in various states, we'd recommend breaking that out into a separate row (with the same transactionId) on the CSV template. Then, in the last column of the attached example template, place the applicable tax code in the lineItemProductTaxCode column (column Q in the attached CSV). Ultimately, the decision to break this out separately or not is up to you (or the Iron Lion Entries team). If the installation charges are not billed independently, they will be considered taxable along with the rest of the transaction. I am attempting to populate the CSV from our filed reports. Does the order of the columns in the CSV matter or must they stay in the represented positions with "transactionId" in the first column, etc.? Yes‚Äîthe order of the columns within the CSV file needs to remain as it is because Zamp's system is designed to import the sales data with the file's columns in the exact order of our template. I hope this helps, and please let us know if you have any questions!

Here's what we've looked at: We deleted all Action Scheduler history items related to Zamp. We spot-checked a couple of orders to see if they had a Zamp Transaction Status, and they did not. Something is cached or hung up somewhere that is preventing the transaction sync still. Next steps: We'll need to work with the website guy, Peter. I'll follow up here via email with Celina - include calendly and the actions/changes necessary. Maybe we'll meet, or it'll be handled async.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Moving to pending ahead of the call. After reviewing the Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin code looking at zamp-tax/includes/admin/transaction-sync/class-zamp-transaction-sync-batch.php , it appears this could be related to multiple items: The following is similar to situations we worked through at TaxJar for WooCommerce. We may need to involve Arlene Cycle's more technical team for database access, depending on what we find during our call today. Issues After Plugin Reinstallation Several things might cause transactions not to sync to Zamp after reinstallation: Orphaned Action Scheduler Tasks : The plugin uses WooCommerce Action Scheduler to queue batch processing tasks After reinstallation, old scheduled actions might still exist in the database, but the code to handle them might have changed These tasks are stored in the WordPress database in the wp_actionscheduler_actions table Stale Transaction Status Metadata : The plugin stores transaction status as post meta ( zamp_transaction_status ) If an order was previously marked as "Success", it won't be reprocessed by default After reinstallation, this metadata remains but the actual sync state might be different Incomplete Cleanup of Previous Sync Data : Batch progress data is stored in WordPress options with prefixes: zamp_transactions_queue_ for batch queues zamp_sync_progress_ for progress tracking If reinstallation happens during an active sync, these might remain in an inconsistent state Sync Status Inconsistency : The global sync status is stored in the zamp_sync_status option If this is stuck in 'in_progress' after reinstallation, new syncs might be blocked Clearing Caches and Resetting Queues To resolve these issues after reinstallation, you should: Clear Action Scheduler Queue : The plugin has a built-in method: Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_scheduled_actions() This calls as_unschedule_all_actions('zamp_process_transactions_batch', array(), self::SCHEDULER_GROUP) You might need to manually trigger this if the reinstallation didn't properly clean up Clean Up Sync Data : Use Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_sync_data() to remove all sync progress and queue data This removes all options with prefixes zamp_sync_progress_ and zamp_transactions_queue_ Reset Sync Status : Set the sync status back to 'ready': Zamp_Transaction_Sync::set_sync_status('ready') This allows new syncs to be initiated Clear Transaction Status Metadata (if needed): If you want to force reprocessing of previously synced orders, you might need to clear the zamp_transaction_status post meta This would be a custom SQL query against the post meta table The most reliable approach would be to run a cleanup sequence that: Stops any in-progress syncs Clears all scheduled actions Removes all sync-related options Resets the sync status to 'ready' This would give you a clean slate to start syncing transactions again after reinstallation. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- 1. Zamp Plugin UI The Zamp plugin itself appears to provide some admin UI for transaction sync operations, but based on the code reviewed, there is no explicit UI button or menu for a full "reset" or "cleanup" of all sync data and scheduled actions. However: Stopping Sync: There is an AJAX action for stopping sync ( zamp_stop_transaction_sync ), which calls Zamp_Transaction_Sync_Batch::cleanup_scheduled_actions() and resets status. If the plugin‚Äôs admin UI provides a ‚ÄúStop Sync‚Äù or ‚ÄúCancel Sync‚Äù button, using it will clear scheduled actions and reset the sync status. Starting Sync: Starting a new sync ( zamp_start_transaction_sync ) also calls the cleanup method before creating new batches. So, starting a new sync from the UI should clear out old scheduled actions. No "Full Reset" Button: There is no evidence of a UI button to clear all progress, batch queues, or transaction meta in bulk. These are handled in the backend code. 2. WooCommerce Action Scheduler UI WooCommerce (and some plugins) provide an Action Scheduler admin screen at: WooCommerce > Status > Scheduled Actions Here, you can view, search, and manually run or delete scheduled actions, including those for Zamp (look for hooks like zamp_process_transactions_batch ). You can manually delete stuck or failed actions from this screen. 3. WordPress Options / Post Meta No UI for Options Table or Post Meta: WordPress does not provide a native UI to delete custom options (like zamp_sync_progress_* , zamp_transactions_queue_* ) or post meta ( zamp_transaction_status ). You would need a plugin like ‚ÄúWP-Optimize‚Äù, ‚ÄúAdvanced DB Cleaner‚Äù, or direct database access for this. 4. Cache Plugins If you are using a caching plugin (e.g., WP Super Cache, W3 Total Cache), you can clear the site cache from their UI, but this does not affect Action Scheduler or Zamp sync data. Summary Table What you can do from UI How/Where Stop/cancel sync Zamp plugin admin (if button exists) Start new sync (clears queue) Zamp plugin admin View/delete scheduled actions WooCommerce > Status > Scheduled Actions Clear transaction/post meta Not available in default UI Clear plugin options Not available in default UI Clear site cache Cache plugin UI (not related to Zamp sync) If you need a full reset: Use the Zamp UI to stop any running sync. Use the WooCommerce Scheduled Actions UI to delete any stuck Zamp-related actions. For a true ‚Äúfactory reset‚Äù (clearing all progress, queues, and post meta), you would need to run code or SQL, or add a custom admin tool.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Celina, I hope you're doing well! Thanks for your patience here! Our team recently updated the Zamp WooCommerce plugin, and we've provided the updated version. Here are the steps to install this version: Download the zip file containing the updated Zamp Tax WooCommerce plugin from your Onboarding Dashboard here . Uninstall the current 'Zamp Tax' plugin by going to Plugins ‚Äî> Search for 'Zamp Tax' ‚Äî> Deactivate ‚Äî> Delete ‚Äî> Confirm Deletion . Follow steps 3-7 in our installation article here . Confirm that the initial configuration is in place (or set it up) as noted at the bottom of the article linked in step #3. We can share the Zamp API token again if it is needed. We also have additional helpful articles centered around configuring Zamp Tax for WooCommerce in our knowledge base here . Review the new Diagnostics page to ensure everything is configured to receive calculations by navigating to: WooCommerce > Settings > Zamp Tax > Diagnostics I've also removed all the existing WooCommerce Transactions from within the Arlene Cycle Support Zamp account, as they did not include the tax amount collected. We'll want to run another Historical Transaction Syn c once the new plugin version is installed. We're also happy to schedule a call to work through this if that would be helpful. Please let us know if you have any questions!

We share more info about that here , and the NY DOR shares details here . In the Shopify Report here , the total tax collected is $12,616.72 , and Zamp's tax-due estimate is slightly lower (due to time zones, most likely) at $12,606.10 . author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Henry, Thanks for the response. I've looked at May's numbers and most look good, WA looks a bit high in zapped, could you help us check here? Sure! The difference in Zamp's tax-due estimate for Washington versus Shopify is caused by the Washington Business & Occupation (B&O) tax , which is a gross receipts tax that businesses pay to the state on gross sales to customers located within Washington. This is a tax that is not typically collected from customers but is required to be paid when filing WA sales tax returns. The Shopify United States Sales Tax Report shows $3,384.16 in tax collected. The breakdown of the B&O tax is: Retailing - Gross Amount: $38,972.09 - Tax Rate: 0.471% - Tax estimated due: $183.56 . Wholesaling - Gross Amount: $9,693.87 - Tax Rate: 0.484% - Tax Due: $46.92 . Combined B&O total : $230.48 The combined total of tax collected and the B&O tax matches Zamp's tax-due estimate ($ 3,609.77 ) within a few dollars (lower): $3,614.64 . Please let us know if you have any questions.

body: You're welcome, Allie! Would that be the case, then? No‚ÄîAmelia and I were able to find a temporary solution for a tax code that will work for this scenario when utilizing the Zamp API. Amelia will be following up about that shortly! Regarding how to handle this in QuickBooks Online: To my understanding of QuickBooks Online's product and tax settings, it would be best to categorize the product or service item as a Nontaxable item for any of these 3% (or other percentage) fees associated with payment processing. As far as "non-taxable income" goes, I believe that would be a separate account (from sales tax) within QuickBooks Online after reading through this resource and this other resource. I'd still recommend that you confirm with QuickBooks Online support to be sure. Regarding using the "gift card" code: Yes‚Äîthat code could be used here as well. Which would be: R_TPP_GIFT-CARD. The thought process on our end regarding the code Amelia will share is that it falls closer to a category that payment processing fees might be categorized under.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allie, You're welcome; thanks for your patience here! what's the best way to ensure this isn't included in the taxable total on Zamp's reports? The likely best path here would be to create a non-taxable item for credit card fees and then confirm via a test invoice that QuickBooks Online does not calculate tax for the item. If we make a non-taxable item for credit card fees, would it effect the total tax owed if other line items in the invoice are taxable? Or will it be avoided if Quickbooks isn't calculating sales tax on it? In this situation, the item's total amount won't be included in the taxable portion of the sales within Zamp, and it won't affect the tax owed, as Zamp files based on the tax collected. That said, the gross sales associated with the transaction would be slightly different in Zamp (grossed down), as we've discussed in the past. The upcoming and improved Zamp QuickBooks Online integration will help resolve scenarios like this, as we'll then receive taxability information from QuickBooks Online at the line item level (if the integration is used and configured). I hope this helps!

If we implement a 3% upcharge for credit card processing, what's the best way to ensure this isn't included in the taxable total on Zamp's reports? If we make a non-taxable item for credit card fees, would it effect the total tax owed if other line items in the invoice are taxable? Or will it be avoided if Quickbooks isn't calculating sales tax on it? I just want to make sure we're on the same page for June. Thank you! Allie

This would likely simplify the situation and increase accuracy. First, Zamp can provide the tax rates and calculate local sales taxes in Michigan for WooCommerce. Sales tax should also be collected in Minnesota and Texas within WooCommerce. 1) A quick question‚Äîwould you like us to add MI for calculations within Zamp? The Accelerated Tooling Team will still be able to file MI sales tax returns, as this is a separate process from these calculations. 2) If they aren't enabled already, could you please also enable Minnesota and Texas for calculations within WooCommerce? We share how to enable calculations here , and each nexus state (MI, MN, and TX) would need to be added to the nexus states section: Please let me know if you have any questions, and I'm also happy to schedule a call if that would be helpful.

body: Hi Stephanie, Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team reaching out to you on behalf of Accelerated Tooling. It's nice to e-meet you! I wanted to see if you could help us turn off the transaction sync to Zamp from the Accelerated Tooling LLC WooCommerce store. The reason for this is that Chris informed us that WooCommerce Transactions (orders and refunds) are entered into QuickBooks Desktop. Chris provides us with the QuickBooks Desktop data every month, and we aim to ensure that there are no duplicate transactions. We share how to turn off the transaction sync to Zamp in this article , and it involves unchecking this box: Navigate to WooCommerce ‚Äî> Settings ‚Äî> Zamp Tax ‚Äî> Send Transactions . Questions: 1) Does the above make sense, and is there anything we can help you with here? 2) Are sales tax calculations enabled within WooCommerce? This should be the case as far as we know. We haven't seen any Texas or Minnesota transactions sync to Zamp, yet, so our visibility into this is limited. Please let us know if you have any questions! We're also happy to discuss this further during a call .

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes from the call: Todo: Bring transactions forward: Kyle is okay with that, and I will need to run that by Anita. Explained the situation, and Kyle understood. Escalate to eng. Other notes and details: They've conducted extensive testing for July 1st with Zamp and are using Zamp for the filings. They might switch to Zamp calculations. Using the TaxJar API is inexpensive, and we want to avoid the technical work. They discovered that Alaska doesn't return the FreightTaxable flags in TaxJar. In Alaska, some municipalities calculate tax on shipping, while others do not, depending on the locality. Do you know if Zamp has already gotten this right? If so, they might move over. It's not a huge cost savings, but it would be good to have better accuracy. A feature request: Is there a way to look up a tax rate without a total? Just an address. If the address validation includes fields such as tax rate, freight taxable, etc., this could be useful. He's happy to hop on with product and engineering folks to hear their reasoning and why, etc. This is tied to how their ERP works; it stores a tax jurisdiction with a rate for the ship-to location, and they can't tie it to an order.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Mary Beth, A quick follow-up to close the loop here! We've adjusted for the voided invoices by deleting them, as Zamp's Nexus Analysis does not include refunds in its analysis. This is based on our Tax Research Team's recent research, which confirmed transaction types considered in economic nexus thresholds. Zamp typically doesn't have a concept of voided invoices except to create a refund transaction. This way, those won't count towards economic nexus thresholds. We'll follow up with you in the July 2nd email thread to confirm the necessary adjustments have been made for the filings due this month and separately send a tax-due estimate. We appreciate your patience throughout this process!

The total tax collected that we see is $491.22 , which aligns with the combined sum of the tax due, as noted in bold, and the timely filing discount. Here's an updated table with the FL amount updated: State code Period Estimated sales tax FL May 2025 $478.94 GA May 2025 $197.14 IL May 2025 $254.00 MI May 2025 $35.82 MN May 2025 $119.00 OH May 2025 $297.99 UT May 2025 $294.65 VA May 2025 $177.40 Estimated sales tax this month: May 2025 $1,854.94 Please let me know if we have your approval to proceed with the FL filing or if you have any questions.

I'm not worried about it since the taxes are paid and it's settled. The other one does have a tax free exemption because it's a church. I updated it with the API on our end. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for the response; continued patience here! So, it should not be run in EST, it should be run in EDT should it not? Correct! In this situation, a time zone-related difference would be a bit different because of the following: Zamp's API receives date stamps (the transactionDate property) in UTC unless the time zone is specified in the request. I can confirm if this is the case if you or your team could share an example API request with me. Zamp then converts the UTC date/time stamp into EST for Florida. The above means that there can still be a slight variance depending on whether the date/time stamp sent to Zamp was in UTC or if it indicated the time zone was in EST. Here's how to indicate if a date/time stamp is in UTC or EST: For UTC, the date/time value would have a 'Z' at the end like this: 2025-06-09T18:40:00 Z For EST, the date/time value would have a time zone on the end of it, such as '-4:00' for EST (EDT, during Daylight Saving Time), such as: 2025-06-09T18:40:00 -04:00 That said, I don't believe time zones are the cause of the larger difference you've noted for Florida here, and I'll share more details below. The cause of the Florida discrepancy here: After digging into this further, I found that the cause of the difference was related to Order ID 229610 because this transaction was created within Zamp as if it should be fully taxable, and $0 tax was collected: For API integrations such as Wired Watts' integration with Zamp, our tax-due estimates are based on what should have been collected via the Zamp API (the taxDue amount). A few questions: 1) Should this transaction be treated as RESALE (wholesale) or something other than fully taxable? 2) If so, does Wired Watts have the ability to update the transaction via the API? We can sort out a path forward for adjusting to this situation once we have more details. I'm also happy to hop on a call with you if that would be helpful! Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Research: I don't see any negative jurisdictions in FL , so that's not the cause. Time zones don't account for this either, because when adjusting for UTC, there is only one extra transaction worth a few dollars in sales tax. This issue appears to be related to Order ID 229610, as it has $0 tax collected but a taxDue, which is likely due to the API. https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/3319-variance-reviewing-by-transactiontax-table?companyId=cm3j4a2ee01c1jx82bksg33hq&stateCode=FL&startDate=2025-05-01&endDate=2025-05-31

author: ken@wiredwatts.com
body: I understand the idea of the time zone thing if the state was in a separate time zone from us, however, that part of Florida is in the same time zone as us in GA. We are both in the Eastern time zone and practice daylight savings at the same time. We recorded the transaction to take place on 5/1/2024 at 12:40 am as did you. If the transaction came in at that time, it was May 1st when that person placed their order in that city in the United States. The only discrepancy would be daylight savings‚Ä¶ which the United States takes part in. So, it should not be run in EST, it should be run in EDT should it not? Either way, it sounds like it was already paid for, and as you said, the ~$2 is not the issue here. However, I would like to hear your thoughts on this because this does not make our books align with whatever you are doing on your end. As for the major discrepancy, please let me know what you find. As stated earlier, you can take this email as a "Go-Ahead" on the rest of the filings, we don't need to delay that any further. Just hold off on Florida until we can get some clarity. Ken MacMaster +1-80-GOT-WATTS +1(860) 468-9288 WiredWatts.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ken, Thanks for letting us know. We will investigate this and will follow up as soon as we have more details to share. Regarding Transaction ID 841408 , Zamp is placing this transaction within the April 2025 filing period for Florida. This happens because Zamp files in each state based on the state capital's time zone . Because Florida is in the Eastern Standard Time (EST) zone and this transaction had a UTC timestamp of May 1, 2025, at 12:40 AM, it is included in the April 2025 filing. This transaction can be viewed on your Transactions page here . This transaction doesn't explain the full difference here, though. There are a few other items this could be related to, but we'll need to confirm. We'll investigate further and follow up as soon as we can.

body: I am good with filing all of these with the exception of Florida. I cannot figure out how you arrived at that number. However, we pulled a tax rate from you for our records to create that transaction so I am not sure why I don't see it in the Zamp report. I show total tax should be around ~$491. Your total is off by ~$80. Can you show me how you arrived at this number? Ken MacMaster +1-80-GOT-WATTS +1(860) 468-9288 WiredWatts.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Karen and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We investigated this further and confirmed that the difference noted between 'Taxes Due' and 'Tax Collected' is related to the timely filing discounts and the Washington Business and Occupation (B&O) tax. There is some difference here due to sales tax rounding as well. The timely filing discounts can be reviewed on each state's sales tax filing (return) artifact available on your Zamp account's Filing Page here . The discounts vary in name but apply to each state with differences greater than approximately $1.00. In the future, we hope to display the timely filing discount in an easy-to-access way, and we've already started discussions with our engineering team about this. Have a great week!

body: Hi Richard, One quick follow-up! I'd also like to note that we need to hear back about this, have the situation sorted out, and receive approval to file your sales tax returns by the end of the day on Monday (6/16/25) to ensure the filings are processed on time for NY and CA.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Richard, Thanks for your continued patience here! We've confirmed that the tax-due estimate Zamp shared is based on the tax collected from your Shopify store, which includes both in-person POS location sales and online sales. To our understanding, if a business has nexus in a state, sales tax is calculated and collected for in-person locations and online sales. Additionally, Zamp's tax-due estimate includes only the taxes we've seen collected within your Shopify store. I've attached an export of the transactions we've sold to or shipped to customers located in California and New York. It's important to note that the New York filing includes transactions from March 1, 2025, to May 31, 2025, because New York follows a fiscal quarter with a different date range than other states. A couple of quick questions: 1) To review this further and compare directly against Shopify's reporting, could you please share your Shopify store's Collaborator request code ? This code should be under Settings ‚Äî> Users within your Shopify Admin. The collaborator access code is something separate from Zamp's automatic import of your Shopify transactions and allows us to review orders, sales tax reporting, and tax settings. 2) Also, could you let me know if we have your approval to proceed with After Market's filings this month? We've held the filings to allow time to investigate this and ensure we're all on the same page.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Richard, Thanks for reaching out! We're investigating this situation and will follow up as soon as we know more.

body: Hi Sean, Thanks for the update; I understand! Yes‚Äîif this is completed over the weekend, that will give us enough time to get the data into Zamp, for Zamp's system to calculate the estimated tax due, and for us to get an estimate out to you. That said, we would need to have the filings approved and released by the end of the day on Monday. If that would be a stretch or tight turnaround on your end, we can push them into June 2025 to then proceed with $0 filings (with the goal being to file timely, avoid going to the overdue filings queue, and avoid penalties & interest from the state.) What would you say works best for you?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, You're welcome! Have enabled Ohio, do we need to put a tax ID for the zamp calcs to work? Great! Thanks for the update! No‚Äîthe Sales tax ID field is optional, as Shopify notes in their article here (it's a good practice to add the tax ID when one is available). Just so you know, Shopify Tax is handling the sales tax calculations here, as Zamp is unable to calculate sales tax within Shopify. Zamp will, however, provide the economic nexus threshold monitoring, registration, filing, and compliance aspects of the puzzle.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma and Angus, Thanks for your patience here! I don't seem to be able to add members, please could you add Angus to the Zamp portal? Sure! I've added Angus as a user to the Ancient + Brave Zamp portal, and an invite was sent to angus@ancientandbrave.earth . If we should add Tom or others to the Ancient + Brave Zamp portal, please let us know either in this email thread or onboarding@zamp.com. Chris - should all wholesale transactions show as RESALE in Zamp, regardless of nexus/non-nexus/certificate exemption status? Yes‚Äîall wholesale transactions will show up as RESALE within Zamp, and we'd recommend implementing a process around this regardless of nexus/non-nexus considerations. The reason for the above is that some US states exclude Wholesale/Resale transactions from their economic nexus thresholds, and Zamp has logic in place to account for this, state by state. In terms of letting you know test orders to delete from Zamp, is there a deadline to communicate this to you before they get filed? Yes‚Äîwe would need to know which transactions to delete (a date range or IDs/names) by the 5th of the month if Zamp is filing sales tax returns for Ancient + Brave, as that is typically the earliest date we would start filing. Can we also see US sales tax in the order in Shopify? Yes‚Äîonce tax collection is enabled for a state within Shopify, the tax will show up as a line between Subtotal and Total on a Shopify order: Here's an example: I assume I can go ahead and set Ohio up as a state A+B collects tax in on Shopify safely before I go on holiday? Sure, if that works best for you! I'll need to do this before UAT starts, but it makes me nervous that we're using Zamp's live system to test on the test Shopify store - is there not a sandbox we can connect to? I understand, and we can certainly switch to using a Sandbox account here instead. I've created an account within Zamp titled "Ancient + Brave Sandbox," and I've invited the following emails as users to this account. hello@emmaforward.co.uk angus@ancientandbrave.earth sophie@highcohesion.com A question here ‚Äîsince we're taking the sandbox approach with this, is it OK if we temporarily disconnect the Shopify store (ancientandbrave-us.myshopify.com) from the production account, named "Ancient + Brave"? I could then also remove any test transactions that have synced so far.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Emma, Thanks for your patience! Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team, and I'm jumping in to help after syncing with Caroline about your questions. Also, I'm in the process of writing the testing scripts for the Shopify integration. Are there any particular testing scenarios you think are worth including? We'd recommend testing some basic scenarios here, and other testing depends on the third-party Shopify apps that are planned for implementation: An order shipping to a nexus state (e.g., Ohio) has tax collected. An order to a non-nexus state (not set up to collect tax) does not have tax collected. Orders for wholesale customers do not have tax collected and show up within Zamp as RESALE on the transactions page. If any third-party apps, such as those listed below, are used, we recommend reviewing those orders to ensure the tax amounts match within Zamp and Shopify (we can help if this is not the case or if these apps are planned). Loop - returns & exchanges. ReturnGo AfterShip Outside of the above, everything should be smooth sailing. I reviewed the Ancient + Brave store and confirmed that products are categorized and Shopify Tax is enabled. Also, once you know that your testing is complete, please let us know, and we can remove the test orders from Zamp by either the Shopify Order ID, Order Name, or a date range. Please let us know if you have any questions!

I didn't see many transactions that had a difference between the Zamp created date and the updated date, meaning it's unlikely there were many updates to the data after we filed. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Andy, You're welcome, and I'm glad these details have been helpful! Great! We understand that process changes take time, and we appreciate your patience as we work through these scenarios. Sometimes, (like this month or last month), we can accurately sort through it later in the month than we'd like. We still have some outstanding items surrounding wholesale transactions and order edit review in historical periods that we're working through (it's taken much longer than expected due to the volume of data and unexpected delays on our end). OK, understood regarding wholesale transactions. Please let us know if the scenarios arise where tax is refunded or if you have any questions. You're very welcome! We're all set now and we'll be sure to reach out if anything comes up! Have a great rest of your week!!

body: Hey Chris, Thanks for the follow-up - really appreciate the thorough breakdown and the supporting reports. I've shared this with our team. The tax per state looks good to me and I've already approved it for payments. I also really appreciate the effort you're putting in to make sure everything reconciles correctly - it's important we're only paying taxes we're actually responsible for. Regarding Wholesale transactions : What typically happens on our end is that the customer reaches out letting us know tax was incorrectly applied, and we either have to reimburse them or they short pay the invoice, which then requires us to manually correct the order. Going forward, we'll tighten this up to ensure anything tagged as WholesaleNoTax is properly exempted and doesn't have tax collected. Appreciate your help on all of this - let me know if anything else is needed from our side. Best, Andy

body: Hi Nick, Thanks for the response and your patience here. To our understanding (and Stripe's), the products (subscription) would be fully taxable in Texas, and the 80% alternate rate wouldn't apply here. Ultimately, the decision on how to proceed is up to you, but I wanted to ensure we're on the same page. This was noted on 5/12: On the surface, the Texas sales tax calculation piece is correct to our knowledge for Software as a Service (SaaS), and we'll confirm CT's tax rate for this product type. As soon as we've confirmed these details or have more information to share, we'll follow up immediately. If you wish to categorize your product as Software as a Service (SaaS) within Stripe, that would achieve the goal of charging 80% of the full rate in TX with these codes: txcd_10103000 - Software as a service (SaaS) - personal use txcd_10103001 - Software as a service (SaaS) - business use Zamp's filing service would support the 80% alternate rate if Stripe is categorized with one of the codes noted above. Please let us know if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, I hope you are doing well. I‚Äôm following up on the tax treatment of your Substack newsletter as a digital good in Texas and Connecticut, as our Tax Research Team shared some additional context and discovered an item specific to Connecticut. In Texas , a Substack newsletter is classified as a digital good, treated as tangible personal property under Texas Tax Code ¬ß 151.009 . This means it is subject to the full sales tax rate, similar to physical goods, and not at the reduced 80% taxable threshold that applies to certain services like information or data processing services ( Texas Tax Code ¬ß 151.351 ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, not a service. Specifically, downloadable articles (txcd_10303000) and non-downloadable articles ( txcd_10304102 ) are taxable sales in Texas. In Connecticut , digital goods are also considered tangible personal property and are generally subject to the standard 6.35% sales tax rate, as outlined in Special Notice 2018(8) . However, after further review, Connecticut exempts sales of newspapers, whether in physical or electronic form, from sales tax under Conn. Gen. Stat. ¬ß 12-412(114) . As a result, both downloadable ( txcd_10303000 ) and non-downloadable ( txcd_10304102 ) newsletter articles are exempt from sales tax in Connecticut. It‚Äôs worth noting that some platforms, like Stripe, may not distinguish between electronically supplied goods or services in their general categories, such as the Stripe Tax code txcd_10000000 , which is currently configured. This means that if the path to not distinguish between downloadable and non-downloadable is taken, Stripe and Zamp would treat Citrinitas' newsletter product as taxable in both CT and TX. I hope this is helpful, and please let us know if you have any questions.

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, I hope this message finds you well. I‚Äôm reaching out to follow up on the tax treatment of your Substack newsletter as a digital good in Texas and Connecticut. In Texas, a Substack newsletter is classified as a digital good, treated as tangible personal property under Texas Tax Code ¬ß 151.009 . This means it is subject to the full sales tax rate, similar to physical goods, and not at the reduced 80% taxable threshold that applies to certain services like information or data processing services ( Texas Tax Code ¬ß 151.351 ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, not a service. Specifically, downloadable articles (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS) and non-downloadable articles (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER) are both taxable sales in Texas. In Connecticut, digital goods are also considered tangible personal property and are generally subject to the standard 6.35% sales tax rate, as outlined in Special Notice 2018(8) . However, after further review, Connecticut exempts sales of newspapers, whether in physical or electronic form, from sales tax under Conn. Gen. Stat. ¬ß 12-412(114) . As a result, both downloadable (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS) and non-downloadable (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER) newsletter articles are exempt from sales tax in Connecticut. It‚Äôs worth noting that while some platforms, like Stripe, may not distinguish between electronically supplied goods or services in their general categories. Best, Ashley I think I'm stuck on what product tax code they should be using to be sure that their product is taxed appropriately. I hope that this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: From Tax Research (Mira) here: https://linear.app/zamptax/issue/TBD-349/request-confirmation-on-ptc-taxability-for-substack-in-texas-and 1.¬†¬†Should a Substack newsletter be considered a digital good within Texas and Connecticut's definitions? Yes, an online newsletter is a digital good within both states, but the taxation varies (see below). 2.¬†¬†Are digital goods in Texas fully taxable or taxed at a reduced rate or threshold of 80%, like SaaS is? Digital goods in Texas are taxed like tangible personal property. TX Letter Ruling 20005359L indicates that digital products are tangible personal property as defined in TX Tax Code ¬ß 151.009 ("'Tangible personal property' means personal property that can be seen, weighed, measured, felt, or touched or that is perceptible to the senses in any other manner, and, for the purposes of this chapter, the term includes a computer program and a telephone prepaid calling card."). The 80% tax situation applies only to information services and data processing services ( TX Tax Code ¬ß 151.351 ). "Information service" is defined as "furnishing general or specialized news or other current information" unless it is furnished to a physical, printed newspaper licensed by the Federal Communications Commission ( TX Tax Code ¬ß 151.0038(1) ). Substack's digital newsletter is a product, ‚Äãnot a service‚Äã. The service of providing information to a newspaper is different from the digital newspaper/newsletter that is produced and distributed. As long as Substack categorizes its product as a digital newsletter (rather than some sort of service), it has to treat it as a digital good. Therefore, in Texas, R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS for downloadable articles and R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER for non-downloaded articles are both taxable sales (which we have correct in our system). 3 - Would a digital good be considered fully taxable in CT or taxed at a 1% rate? Special Notice 2018(8) indicates that digital goods are included in the definition of tangible personal property and are taxed at the 6.35% rate effective Oct. 2019. However, sales of newspapers, whether sold as physical copies or electronically accessed or transferred are exempt from sales tax ( Conn. Gen. Stat. ¬ß 12-412(114) ). Therefore, in Connecticut, R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS for downloadable articles and R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS_PERIODICALS_NEWSPAPER for non-downloaded articles are both exempt sales (which we have correct in our system). I also want to point out that Stripe does not distinguish between an electronically supplied good or service at the "general" category that appears on Substack's support article . But for tax purposes, it is a vital distinction. It's up to the customer to classify their product correctly. In my opinion, a newsletter is a digital good, not a service. Let me know if I can be of further help!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nick, Thanks for your patience here! We talked about this internally and wanted to share the details previously noted by our Tax Research and Content Team and how we would view this situation. Overall, Zamp understands and interprets that Citrinitas' offerings would be fully taxable at the full rate for Connecticut and Texas. The above interpretation is due to Citrinitas' offering being viewed as a digital good, separate from Software products/services, where the TX 80% reduced rate rule applies; this is also our view of the 1% rate for CT . From our understanding, Substack allows writers to share information via written format, podcasts, and videos. All three are digital products, or as Maine calls them, "products transferred electronically." This fits with the support article that advises using "General‚ÄîElectronically Supplied Services." It seems like Citrinitas has some articles that can be downloaded and some that cannot. The ability to download matters in some states. Therefore, if they ‚Äãdo not‚Äã want to differentiate between which articles can be downloaded and which cannot, they can use R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS (which will tax both types of articles). Chris R Note - this is currently what the existing Stripe Tax code maps to, within Zamp. If they do want to make the distinction between downloadable and non-downloadable, these tax codes can be used: The Stripe Tax code for downloadable articles: txcd_10303000 The Stripe Tax code for non-downloadable articles is: txcd_10304102 Next steps: That being said, we will triple-check with our Tax Research team to confirm this interpretation and for any additional context that comes with our advisory services. As soon as we have more details, we'll follow up immediately. Have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body:
Hi Nicole, Thanks for confirming these details! I've imported the credit memo, and that change is now reflected in our tax-due estimate. Regarding #2 ‚Äîyes, that's correct! These would be related to any credit memos not sourced from Shopify and are processed within QuickBooks Online. Below is the updated tax-due estimate, but first, I wanted to share some details about the difference for Colorado. Regarding Colorado: The $42.60 difference for Colorado is related to a refund transaction (#1899), causing the tax amount for the Denver, CO local jurisdictions within the CO filing to become negative. This applies to the City, County, and special tax (e.g., transportation or facilities-related districts). God's True Cashmere didn't have enough sales in these jurisdictions throughout April 2025 to cover the full refunded tax amount. A portion of the refunded tax is excluded from the filing because the Colorado Department of Revenue (DOR) doesn't allow negative amounts in local jurisdictions when filing Colorado returns; the majority of states don't allow this. In a situation like this, Zamp would need to file the sales tax return in CO as it is or after removing the refund transaction. As an exception, we can move this refund transaction into the May 2025 filing period to be processed in June 2025 if you'd like us to. Please note that we'll need to know how to proceed here by the end of the day (EST) tomorrow, May 15th, 2025 , to file for God's True Cashmere in a timely manner. If we cannot proceed or don't hear back, the filings will need to move into our overdue filings queue and could be subject to state-applied penalties & interest. Please let us know if you have any questions! Here's the updated tax-due estimate: üóìÔ∏è Returns due in May In the table below, we have provided the estimated tax due for God's True Cashmere, LLC. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Israel and Team, Thanks so much for your patience here! My name is Chris. I'm part of the Technical Success Team here at Zamp, and we've been investigating the differences noted for the November 2025 filing period. After further review, it appears that Shopify Tax collected amounts for the October 2024 filing period (10/1/24-10/31/24) were used for the comparison on the 'Zamp-Filings' sheet of the file you shared. I've attached a modified version of your XLSX file with an extra sheet showing the November 2024 Shopify tax collected amounts on their own; this is on the 'Z Shopify Review - Nov 24' sheet. The 'Zamp-Filings' sheet has been updated with those amounts. That said, we're still seeing close to a 12% difference between Zamp and Shopify for Oklahoma and Rhode Island ; those are highlighted in blue. In both of these states, Zamp filed overdue returns in January 2025, while they were due in December 2024. The differences here are due to penalties & interest assessed by the state. The differences that are under or within ~2% are very likely due to timely filing discounts, rounding, or time zone differences; we share more info about that here . We also reviewed your account for known third-party apps (such as Loop, which Zamp accounts for and appears to be appropriately configured) or edge-case scenarios that might cause differences. A quick question: Which Shopify Report do you use to reconcile and compare? In our Comparison, we used the Shopify United States Sales Tax Report because Velvet Caviar uses Shopify Tax for the calculations. We've found this report to typically align closely with Zamp (with a few differences noted above). It also appears that you're likely using this report, but we wanted to confirm. If you'd like to discuss this on a call next week or sometime soon, please use this link to schedule a call . Have a wonderful weekend!

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Israel, Thanks for reaching out! I'm happy to address these items. When registering in California, the state flagged the original nexus start date as potentially being after the point of crossing the economic threshold and they wanted Velvet Caviar to reassess this information. After further conversation with Paul, the nexus start date was reassessed to March 1, 2023. This was resolved in February after the Q4 2024 deadline resulting in penalties and interest associated with the filing. This is the difference you are seeing for this period. We are reviewing these periods and will keep you updated. Thank you! In New York, you are on a quarterly prepayment filing frequency so the majority of the tax had already been submitted as "Advance payments". You can find this on your New York Q4 2024 return on page 8. I hope that this helps to clarify and please let me know if you have any further questions! In the meantime, we will work to look closer at November. Best, Ashley

Just a heads up: the Shopify report I'm using includes returns in the tax totals. Lastly, regarding New York : it looks like we began filing monthly starting in December, but the Q4 NY filing totals only show about $11K-did we potentially miss a month? Please note that internet communications are not secured and therefore are susceptible to alteration.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @ashleyD - I've looked into this some, and will have more time throughout today/tomorrow. So far, I see very few Loop transactions that overstate the tax due because we see Loop exchange transactions without tax listed (which would mean they probably have the Loop Discount disabled, which is what we want). https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clv2sou8001uto8m6dh2m8ykj/transactions?search=EXC&date=2025-01-01%7E2025-05-08&limit=100 That said, there are ~15-18 transactions since we started filing (8/1/23-5/8/25) where Loop transactions associated with exchanges have tax associated with them; these would typically cause duplicate tax. We'll need to dig into this further, but these can also be adjusted for within future periods. https://zamp.metabaseapp.com/question/5644-find-shopify-loop-exchange-transactions-with-tax-collected-v2?company=clv2sou8001uto8m6dh2m8ykj&start=2023-08-01&end=2025-05-08 We'll also need to manually review their Shopify transactions vs. Zamp transactions because they're using Avalara for tax calculations in Shopify , which is trickier to investigate. (We don't have the Shopify US Taxes report to work off of, just the 'taxes' report , which I'll need to review more.) That said, Zamp's estimate is under the total tax collected for April 2025 in the 'Taxes Report', but that's likely due to filing frequency differences and time zones.

author: nkondak@zamp.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @nick - This could be a good reconciliation to dive into if you'd like to. We'd need to use: The United States sales tax report and the Transactions version of that report. I'd usually run the Shopify forced recon script here, and we still could, but I did that already for this customer before filing. We'd likely want to look at the results of Variance reviewing and j urisdiction-level queries to see if anything stands out. Suppose they have a bunch of refunds in various states, making the amount in the jurisdiction-level query negative. If the amount is negative and ends up being close to the difference here, that is likely the culprit. There's a good chance the differences are just time zones, rounding, etc, as the overall difference is only ~6.6%, but it's high in some states. Lucas or I are happy to help with this too, if there are questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, You're welcome, and thanks for confirming! For Invoice 5894, I believe what is happening here is related to some updates we made to our QuickBooks Online export processing script that are likely improperly processing the street address (the way QuickBooks Online formats/stores their addresses can make some of this tricky). We use the zip code to determine the state a transaction belongs in, but for some reason, it's using the full address. We'll revert our script updates or find a way around this situation. We'll sort this out today, review all other transactions, and likely re-import the data to ensure accuracy.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: This is the transaction: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0em12uc000027p2ohfjwuue/transactions?search=5894&timezone=US/Local&date=2024-01-01~2025-05-20 For some reason, the zip code is completely wrong here. The address portion's numbers match the zip code, though. So, the script likely messed something up here and needs to be changed.

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Thanks Chris for looking into this! The amounts themselves make sense now, so appreciate the fix there. I'm wondering why transaction ID #5894 is pulling into PA though, as both billing and shipping address are in Maryland. That's the transaction that's putting us over Nexus. Lemme know if it's best to call and discuss! Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, Another follow-up here! We have properly adjusted the amounts using the exchange rate provided in QuickBooks Online and dividing the 'Amount' and 'Tax Amount' values by that rate. For transactions where the invoice was in CAD but billed to a US address, we used an exchange rate of 1.34. I've attached a file showing the work (this Zamp Sales Tax QBO Report) around the exchange rate math and the file we imported into Zamp. I've also attached a file showing the current transactions in Zamp because we still see over $100k in sales to PA from 5/1/24 to 4/30/25, one of the periods used to evaluate PA economic nexus thresholds. This is using a mix of data from Stripe and QBO. A few questions: 1) Do you know if the files look right to you regarding the amounts? 2) Do you know if the PA Transactions still match your expectations?

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body: Hey Chris! I just saw this notification and dug in since we definitely don't have $100k USD in PA transactions. But I think I found the issue üòä What I believe is happening is that things are importing with a translation issue. If we're using the foreign currency, then the integration is multiplying by the currency conversion rate instead of what we should be doing, which is dividing. As an example, Invoice 6448 should total $18,000 USD but is showing up as ~$36,800 USD in Zamp (see attached screenshots). If I take the QBO canadian amount of $25,734.33 CAD, and divide it by $18,000 USD, that implies a 1.429685 exchange rate. But $25,734.33 * 1.429685 = $36,791.99 which is what is showing up in Zamp. Let me know what you think or if you would like to chat through! Cheers, Bill

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, You're welcome, and we greatly appreciate your continued patience here! We're still evaluating the situation and data from multiple angles. We've had a few unexpected delays. So far, we haven't found evidence of transactions sold through Marketplace Platforms having tax attributed to them within Zamp because Zamp will attribute a $0 transaction tax value for Meta, Shop, and TikTok if our integration "knows" that the transaction is from one of those channels. By extension, this should mean that the Taxes Collected Report shouldn't include Marketplace Facilitator tax collection. This situation is tricky because, to my understanding, not all SHOP transactions will be associated with Marketplace Facilitator tax collection. That said, I'd like to be sure we're on the same page and have a couple of quick questions: Note‚ÄîI will also sync with Ashley about this when we're all back from the US holiday this weekend. 1) Which Marketplace or Shop Channel transactions do you see tax collection for, within Zamp? 2) If a specific transaction wasn't the cause of the concern, was this related to differing amounts in the liability review process? 3) To ensure we're comparing and reviewing the same data sources, could you please let us know which Shopify Reports were used in this liability review and reconciliation process? Was it the United States Sales Tax Report , the Taxes Report , or something else? Have a wonderful weekend!

Currently the only two reports available are the 1) Taxes Collected report and the 2) Tax Liability report. The tax collected report includes taxes collected on marketplace platforms so this report overstates our liability. While the tax liability provides a fairly accurate tax liability for states that are reported monthly, however the tax liability report does not provide the tax liability for states with a quarterly, semi-annual or annual reporting requirement like Illinois which has an annual reporting. Any help on providing a report that would support our tax liability would be greatly appreciated. Thanks, Sandy Jones Iron Clad Consulting Controller

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Sandy, Thank you for sending over these questions! We are happy to address these. Shopify Shop is a Marketplace facilitator which means that they are responsible for collecting and remitting sales tax related to Shopify Shop sales channel. You can find additional information here . While you are not responsible for collecting and remitting sales tax, we do still include these transactions in your sales tax returns and they will be reflected as a Marketplace exemption/deductions (depending on the state's requirements). The transaction IDs (6005407449255 and 6005255405735) are related to Shopify Shop transactions and are reported on your sales tax returns but you are not responsible for remitting the tax collected by Shopify Shop. We are receiving your TikTok transactions via Shopify. However, you are not responsible for remitting the sales tax collected by Shopify as they are also a Marketplace facilitator. I'm happy to gain more information on your additional questions on a call. Feel free to schedule a time that works best for you here . Best, Ashley

author: sandy.jones@go-ironclad.com
body: Good afternoon, Client - David Protein We are trying to ensure that all sales tax collected is being remitted to the proper governmental agencies.  In our analysis, we have found transactions that are not being remitted as they should.  I'd like to set up some time to understand why Zamp is not reporting and sending sales tax on the following Shop Channel Transactions and what needs to be done to correct this.  I could not find a way within Zamp to set up a time to discuss these issues so I am reaching out via email. Following are the general areas that I would like to discuss with you: Shopify Payments - the majority of the transactions are flowing through to Zamp with a few exceptions.  For example, transaction ID 6005407449255 - Shopify shows $2.56 in sales tax collected but Zamp did not report these taxes. TikTok - This looks like an integration we may need to add as no TikTok transactions are being reported.  How do we go about getting this Channel added in Zamp? Shop Cash / Shopify Payments - when a customer uses Shop Cash, Zamp is not remitting the sales tax - Is this a separate integration?  Why would this be?  For example, transaction ID 6005255405735 - Shopify shows $6.24 in sales tax collected but Zamp did not report these taxes. How are returns handled?  Do they just flow into the next month's reporting? How do we go about getting the previous month's sales tax reported/sent to the proper governmental authorities? I have copied Sam Bauman, David Protein's Director of Finance, if you need any authorization to speak to me on his account.  Please suggest a few times when we could discuss the above or send me a link to select a time to meet. Thanks, Sandy Jones Iron Clad Consulting Controller (928) 261-0357

body: Hey Andrew, Sorry for the hold up here. I went through all transactions with a note attached and was actually surprised at how many were accurate . For example, 74075 shows all the correct logic, following best accounting principles: - Taxable transaction - Refunded transaction - Recreated transaction as exempt On the other hand, the exact same scenario is a bust for some reason (74018): - Taxable transaction - Refunded transaction - Recreated transaction as exempt - Refunded the recreated transaction as exempt. For some of the other orders where there was an adjustment/change, I noticed we didn't create the transaction with the appropriate change, or it was just left as refunded. This was the case for 140162 and 140425. I had corrected these. In either case, the guys are going to kick a new notice your way that is mathematically sound to the transaction exports I did from BigCommerce. I'm going to take these issues to my write-up for the integration developers. Thanks! Ryan

body: Hey Andrew, Yeah! More to share and a new notice end of week. I shared this with the team internally earlier. I wrote something to handle a comparison where the order notes field was used to look at the records in Zamp. It produces a trail to show all coinciding transactions produced on our end. This also works as a precursor to looking back at old records from before we talked about using the order notes field. The "Difference" log line is a comparison of the "Order Total (Inc Tax)" from a BigCommerce orders export to the Zamp net total after all the records. There are some examples further down the trail where the difference is more apparent. I think there were a total of 14 orders across SSM and PSP that have order notes from April. This work will continue into the end of the week, when I hope to clear getting a new notice your way from our team. As for the actual app and corrections to the integration itself, still getting the details together for the team that manage the integration. We're still closing out some prior work. Thanks for your patience,

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, I won't argue too much about whether the /addresses validation is correct or not other than to say that our customer entered a valid address and your API marked it as invalid. Any technicalities or specific configurations that caused it doesn't invalidate the fact that the API got it wrong and caused the customer justifiable frustration. Regardless, we have already implemented such functionality in our checkout process. It displays a simple warning when the address entered is marked as invalid by the inconsistent /addresses validator, and it allows the checkout to continue without sales tax calculation in such cases. Thanks, Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the response! No‚ÄîI was referring to a slightly different configuration (and likely UI updates) or checkout flow to ensure address validation doesn't prevent the customer from continuing through checkout. I've seen Magento or WooCommerce implement address validation in this way and have heard from clients I worked with in roles elsewhere of similar changes (this might be a big lift, and is not necessarily required.) From our standpoint, the /addresses validation is correct as it was initially built and needs a configuration tweak. Zamp uses more data sources with higher accuracy overall, or at least simply a different way of processing the data (From the Google Maps API), which can result in variance with other address validation services. I hope this helps!

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, Are you suggesting integrating into Google Maps API because the /addresses validation is incorrect? Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the update! I understand. In a situation like this and in general, it might be worth implementing some 'select an address' functionality to display the original address and the updated address, if any; if there isn't another address, allow the checkout process to proceed. In general, address validation shouldn't prevent the checkout process from completing. We also understand if this isn't an option here.

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hi Chris, Sounds good. We will be unable to fully utilize the address validation until that is put in place. It shouldn't be a huge deal. Thanks, Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, A quick follow-up here! Our Engineering Team told me that Zamp viewed the address as invalid because of a data and geolocation quality indicator we have in place for address validation. Here's a bit of detail: Zamp's /addresses API endpoint is currently configured to allow only rooftop or parcel address precision confidence levels, and we receive a zip9 response for this address, but we also received an indicator that DPV = 'Y' This happens because Zamp utilizes a different address validation solution than Google, with a broader mix of data. We found a strategy here that would allow addresses with a DPV value of Y for this scenario and cast a wider net for valid addresses, an indicator tied to the data existing within a USPS dataset. We've passed along a feature request that would add the DPV item noted above to the validation ruleset, and we hope to have it released in the future. Once this is released, we'll be sure to follow up!

author: ebasham@bondware.com
body: Hello there, We have a customer that has entered a valid address and yet the /addresses validator is saying it is invalid. [ "line1" => "501 Ridge Rd" "city" => "Fairfield" "state" => "ME" "zip" => "04937" "country" => "US" ]According to Google Maps validation, this is a perfectly valid address https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/address-validation/demo 501 Ridge Road Fairfield, ME 04937 Until this is resolved, I think I will have to disable the address validation. Quite frustrating for our customers. Thanks, Ethan B

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tracey, Thanks for checking in! We've resolved the differences, and an updated tax-due estimate will be sent out within the next few minutes. The good news is that our filing team will be able to file these returns on time, and there will be no late charges from the states. We keep these dates in mind as we work through various situations, and we'll communicate this more clearly going forward. For Illinois and Iowa filings, we have until 5/15/2025 to file on time, ideally we would file before that date. We looked into this further and found the following items contributed to the differences here: For Iowa , we found that Transaction ID 144 had a date of 4/29/ 26 instead of 4/29/ 25 , causing the transaction to be placed in a future filing period. We have updated this, and we've made improvements to prevent situations like this from occurring in the future. For Illinois , we found that the difference you noted was due to our tax-due estimate automatically accounting for the Illinois timely filing discount (also known as the 'Retailer's discount'), and that estimated amount is $398.00 . The IL Retailer's discount is applied when filing on time and is 1.75% of the sales tax collected. Please let us know if you have any questions. I hope that you have a wonderful weekend!

For now, we are holding your filings as we work towards investigating this further, and we'll be sure to keep the state filing due dates in mind to ensure timely filing. We appreciate your patience!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tammy and Team, I hope you're doing well! Chris here with the Zamp Technical Success Team following up about the differences Tammy noted in another email thread with Caroline. We appreciate your patience with this. After further investigation, we found that Zamp had $0 listed as the estimated tax-due amount for Virginia and Illinois because Zamp views your product as tax-exempt in those states. In these situations, we can ask our filing team to file the tax collected amount instead of the tax-due amount. I understand that the Bondaware team has filed the April 2025 returns; we'll note this on the Zamp side. I'll sync with Caroline tomorrow about how or if those amounts must be recorded within Zamp.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: @caroline - you're welcome! Of course! TL;DR - I realized this is happening because Zamp views this customer's product (with the R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS tax code) as tax-exempt . So, the IL and VA notices are generating with $0 tax due. I can share a more detailed breakdown and how to spot this in ~1 hour. I'll follow up with the customer too, if that would help, but wanted to tirple-check with you first: Were they expecting us to pay the tax they collected, or were they going to refund the tax collected (Technically, over-collected) to their customers?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Heather, Thanks for sending this over! To ensure we're on the same page, are we wondering why the 'Tax Collected' and 'Tax Due' values differ? If the above is the case, I've outlined our findings for the states noted below. Colorado - This difference is due to the CO's timely filing discount. Florida - this difference is also due to a timely filing discount for FL. Illinois - This is another difference due to the timely filing discount for IL. Washington‚ÄîThis difference is caused by the Business & Occupation gross receipts tax (0.471% of all transactions) due when filing sales tax returns in CO, which is 34.97. If the above helps and makes sense here, it appears that adjustments won't be needed for the April 2025 filing period, we can skip the adjustment imports this month, and send the tax-due estimate out, today. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sarita, Thanks for your patience with this! I checked in with our Head of Filing, who noted that if we cannot access the Shipping address details in Target's order exports and sales tax report exports, we can place the Target Plus transactions into a zip code within that state. Ultimately, our primary recommendation is to either implement a third-party tool like Acenda (or something similar, but this isn't an endorsement) or contact Target Plus Seller Support via the Target Plus portal to find a way to obtain an export from Target Plus with the shipping address data. Working with Target Plus Seller Support is likely the best path forward here. It may involve submitting a ticket to them (or emailing them) via the 'Support' section on the left-hand side of the portal, as during our call, we saw that the 'support' option was some chatbot. When you have a moment, could you please share a CSV file with the Target Plus transaction data listed by state? I'm also happy to hop on another quick call if you'd like to discuss any of this or have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: I had a call with Sarita about this, today. For the Target data: Possibility: Can we pick a random city, state, or zip code to associate the transactions? They can get totals per state from a sales tax export from Target. The orders exported don't contain addresses, but they contain amounts. The returns export doesn't contain amounts, but it includes a return location, sometimes.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sarita, Thanks again for your patience! We reviewed the Target Plus file and found that while it does contain some of the information we need, it's missing the Ship To Address details. To import and use the data in sales tax filings, Zamp would need at least the Ship To Zip code , or the Ship To City and Ship To State . Also, Zamp would need every row in the CSV file to contain amounts (discounts, subtotal, etc.) and a transaction date. Unfortunately, we haven't had to export data from Target Plus yet, as we haven't received this kind of request in the past. If we find or think of any customers also selling through Target Plus, we'll ask them how they approach it. That said, we did some research here and this is what we've found: The Target Plus Reports do not contain the shipping addresses. A third-party tool like Acenda could obtain an export that includes the Shipping address ( ChannelEngine and other tools don't appear to have this ability, but there may be others). We don't specifically endorse any tool here, as this is new to us. It might be best to contact Target Plus Seller Support via their portal using the help/support features. Target Guest Relations may also be able to direct you to the correct department by calling 1-800-440-0680. Based on our research (what we can find online), it is not easy to get the data Zamp would need for Target Seller Plus sales. If you can see a way to obtain the city and state for the orders within Target Plus, we could use that data, but otherwise, it appears to be tricky to accomplish this. If you'd like, we're also happy to schedule a call with this link to share your screen and see if we can find any way around Target Plus' limitations here. If a time on my calendar won't work for you, please let me know what days and times work for you, and I'll check with other folks at Zamp to see who might be available. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger and Team, Thanks for your patience here! We found a few root causes related to the difference here, and I've outlined those below. Refund Transactions with discounts where the tax refunded was lower in Zamp than Shopify‚Äîour engineering team is monitoring this, and an improvement is in progress. Order Edits to Shopify orders via Shopify's built-in return/exchange functionality. Shopify's APIs don't expose much of this to Zamp, and what we've seen in the past has been inconsistent and inaccurate. Our engineering team has this on their list to explore solutions for the future. A couple of edge case-related Shopify voided/canceled orders. This is also on our engineering team's radar. Please note that Shopify's tax amounts (within the US Sales Tax Report ) have changed a bit since the initial email: We've adjusted for the differences here and will send you an updated tax-due estimate. For now and until the features/improvements noted above are released, we'll account for these scenarios before sending the tax-due estimate in the future. Please let us know if you have any questions!
