author: chris@zamp.com
body: @lucas - Thanks for your patience! After looking into the order examples you shared, the differences with these orders occur due to a form of order editing that uses Shopify's native (but newer) return/exchange functionality. We can tell this is the case when orders show removed/added items or note 'partially refunded' OB47903 From looking at the transactions page below, we show a remaining $9 for sales tax, but Shopify shows $7.92, so we're off a bit here; that's likely part of the cause (or all.) https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB47903&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 This is likely related to this in-progress feature request (issue..): https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/40979248/card_tables/cards/8390180624 ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- OB50115 This one looks like an order edit, but it also uses Shopify's return functionality. We don't even have the correct tax amount because of the order edit (removing an item directly in Shopify's UI): The Zamp transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB50115&timezone=US/Local&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 $0 for a return/refund and $26.56 for tax. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî OB49868 This one is a voided/canceled order that is related to a different, known, issue. The order was never fulfilled and was voided, which Zamp doesn't currently capture. Zamp transactions: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cly91ak1a00s8dpclt7hkljzb/transactions?search=OB49868&timezone=US/Local&date=2025-01-01~2025-05-08 Related issue: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/40979248/card_tables/cards/8390148844 ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- The solution for these: We can take the path outlined below because we don't see negative balances in local jurisdictions using this query (for Georgia at least). We should run the Shopify forced reconciliation script here: https://github.com/zamptax/zamp-technical-success/tree/main/utility/scripts/shopify_forced_recon_offset Then, after we allow an hour for the forced reconciliation adjustment transactions to be factored in, compare the Zamp notice amounts (the MB query here ) against the US taxes report to see if they're closer. I can do that today or tomorrow if that's better, or we can run through it together!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Catherine, Thanks so much for your patience here! I investigated this and found that Shopify support is correct here as far as I can tell, unless tax collection was never enabled for California. It seems that Shopify either defaulted to collecting taxes when an in-person CA location was added, or it was turned on at some point. Currently, the CA tax collection appears to be disabled per this Shopify taxes report. This appears to be related to the NC Crane AG location's address in San Luis Obispo County, which can be found in Shopify here . Shopify also shares a bit of detail about this here ,  when viewing this location in Shopify and on the ' Manage tax liability ' page here (also shown below): The tax collection for San Luis Obispo County and the city of CA could be correct based on the various tax rules within CA, as that is where this POS location is currently listed. We share more details about this in our California Sales Tax Guide here . We would call this intrastate sales tax sourcing, but as Shopify notes , it's sometimes called 'hybrid origin' sourcing. This type of tax collection involves collecting the California state tax, the county and local taxes of the in-person location, and the city and district taxes associated with the shipping address. The above would be correct if Semaine Health does have a physical location within San Luis Obispo County, is registered to collect and file taxes in CA, and the ' Hybrid-Origin ' tax setting was selected for CA: Zamp's sales tax API would calculate similarly if we knew that Semaine Health had this exact location. If you're not registered to collect in CA (we don't see that listed as such in Zamp) and aren't filing CA returns outside of Zamp, we recommend refunding the taxes collected to your customers if you haven't done so already. Suppose the CA tax wasn't enabled and the 'Hybrid-Origin' option wasn't selected. In that case, we'd recommend you continue to escalate this with Shopify for further investigation (based on our understanding of Shopify's settings and documentation). I understand that the above is a lot of information, which can be tricky (especially when explaining it to a customer). We're happy to hop on a call to discuss this sometime if you'd like! Do you think the above helps answer the situation here? If not, please let us know; we'll clarify! Please let us know if you have any questions, and have a great weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: This is probably some Shopify Tax or Avalara setting or something. Need to investigate within their Shopify store.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Catherine, Thanks for reaching out and for your patience here! We're investigating this, and it's very likely related to some configuration within Shopify (or your tax calculation solution). We hope to share more details by tomorrow.

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Met with Ryan and Tyron to discuss the issue with the NON_PROFIT tax status not working. Ryan determined that he had to use Avalara's tax code mapping which was the letter G. This worked to fix the issue, Ryan is going to check with engineering about resolving this issue in the future.

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Tyron, Would you be available for a call today with Ryan, who is more of an expert with BigCommerce? Please let me know a time that works for you if so.

author: nkondak@zamp.com
body: Hi Tyron, Thank you for your patience on this. If you visit the article here: https://support.bigcommerce.com/s/article/How-do-I-have-customers-with-a-tax-exempt-status?language=en_US Then scroll to the section "Creating Tax-Exempt Customers Using Basic Tax, it will have instructions on how to create a tax group for select customers. You will have to create a group for tax-exempt customers and then assign that specific customer as tax-exempt, similar to the screenshot I attached. This should create a tax-exempt status once assigned correctly.

body: Hi Connor, Thanks for working with us on this! Unfortunately, the 'Criquet Shirts' Shopify Store access still appears pending. This is very strange, and as far as I can tell, you're doing everything correctly. Here's what we see: Is this effecting our filing process? Yes‚Äîwe're currently holding Criquet Apparel's filings until we can run a bulk sync to update some items associated with Criquet's Shopify transactions. This is due to some changes made on Shopify's end, which required updating our integration. The good news is that we're on top of this and will be able to file on time for you. To file timely, we need to ensure your sales tax filings are moving into our process by Monday, 5/12/25. If needed, we have some additional time past that date, but we're hoping to keep things as efficient as possible. ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî- Next steps: 1) Can you hop on a quick call about this so that we can screenshare? Or could you reach out to Shopify Support? I'd love to and am happy to help figure this out. Sometimes, we see delays in Shopify access making its way over to Zamp's partner account, but that's usually no more than a few hours. 2) Alternatively, could you follow the steps below to add the read_locations permission that the Zamp app now needs? I'm also happy to hop on a call to walk through this. Log in to your Shopify admin and select settings ‚öôÔ∏è at the bottom left of your screen. Select "Apps and sales channels." Select the "Develop apps" button at the top right section next to the "Shopify App Store" button. Click on the "Zamp" custom app In the header section, click on "Configuration." Once in the "Configuration" tab, click the Edit button on the "Admin API integration" sectio.n Once in the Admin API access scope selection view, type "read_locations" into the search box, which will filter your options. Then, click the box next to "read_locations" and click the Save button at the top right of the page.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Tzippy, Thanks for meeting with us earlier! Here's the Excel formula I showed during our call: =COUNTIF($C$2:$C2, C2) > 1 These are the steps I follow when using this: Download the data from Zamp. Select all of the values in the ' transactionId ' column (C). Select Conditional Formatting and click ' New Rule '. Change 'Style' to ' Classic ' In the dropdown right beneath ' Style ', select ' Use a formula to determine which cells to format ' Paste the formula into the text box and click "OK". Add filters to the 'transactionId' column and filter it by color, selecting the cell color used in the conditional formatting. Delete the rows that are highlighted. The above steps will leave a single row per order or transaction within the CSV file and can help make reviewing and reconciling with Zamp more efficient. The attached spreadsheet is an export from NSG's Zamp account and already has the formula and conditional formatting in place, as an example. We'll follow up regarding the other Shopify order scenarios as soon as we can!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Xenia and Katrina, You're welcome, and thanks for confirming these details! Based on this article , Shopify Tax won't calculate taxes for an order if it contains one or more products with a tax rate override. However , it may work if the 'charge tax on this product' box is checked or unchecked. It might be a good idea to try setting these up as a shipping profile or a custom flat-rate option instead. That said, Zamp won't know how to treat these products (line items within an order) as shipping because our Shopify integration uses the order-level 'shipping' amount details to automatically handle shipping taxability; we don't currently have a shipping tax code due to this. If no tax is collected, Zamp will not remit tax to the state DOR, and that portion of the transaction(s) would be excluded from the filing. If tax is collected, we'll categorize it in our filings according to the proper jurisdictions, as most states only require shipping to be grouped with Gross Sales. Setting the taxability of these shipping products manually could work if they are marked as tax-exempt. However, we wouldn't want to apply a tax override (rate) here, because Shopify likely won't collect tax on the order. This should work with Zamp. Ultimately, I recommend checking in with Shopify Plus Support to confirm the best path and behavior when using Shopify Tax. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Closing after a call with Ethan, answered questions about product tax codes, taxability, added TN as a nexus state to the test account, and discussed Discounts + amounts + line items and how they factor into the subtotal. Closing for now.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ethan, Thanks for the response! Of course! Let's use this link to schedule a call tomorrow. Most of my availability is in the afternoon (EST), but I can adjust my schedule if a morning time slot is better. Is there an API limit that is silently enforced? If so what is that limit? There is an API rate limit, but it shouldn't be silently enforced. Our API rate limit was recently increased by our engineering team last week and should now be 500 requests per minute. Also could you explain why it's returning so many taxes records for a single line item? Sure! This happens because a taxes object is returned for each tax jurisdiction (state, county, district, etc.), and this occurs for each line item within a transaction. The jurisdiction "type" (which can vary from one state to the next) is indicated by the jurisdictionDivision property's value within the object. How do I correlate these back together? Do I sum up for a given line item? This is a good question! In a situation like this, it would likely be best to sum the taxDue amount for each lineItemId if there are multiple line items; otherwise, the taxDue value above the taxes array could be used if there's only a single line item. Regarding the $0 tax due returned for this calculation: This happened in this request's instance because Zamp currently treats line items with the general digital products tax code (R_DIG_DIGITAL-PRODUCTS) as tax-exempt in Virginia. A way to determine if this is the case is if the taxDue amount in the Zamp calculation response is 0 and the taxableAmount is also 0. I'm also happy to take a look at additional examples. As I can in the morning, I'll review some API calls sent to Zamp for the test account.

Also could you explain why it's returning so many taxes records for a single line item? How do I correlate these back together? Do I sum up for a given line item? Thanks, Ethan B

body: Hi Jason and Bobbi, A quick follow-up here! I've attached a few files for your review, along with the tax-due estimate: Per our usual process, the 'shopify_orders_export_1-edited' file is the source file for accounting for the edited and voided orders. The ' Ravella - Shopify Edit and Void Adjustments ' file is the adjustments file imported into Zamp to account for this. The 'RAVELLA Zamp Export' file contains all the transactions used for the underlying estimates and filings within Zamp. A quick note about the differences you'll see in the last file vs. the tax-due estimate: The tax-due estimate has an amount that is very much an estimate, which does not fully account for all of the CA prepayments already made (our engineering team has in-progress improvements to better account for this), and here's the breakdown of those payments: The total tax collected was $18,116.00 . The January 2025 prepayment was $6,552.00 . The February 2025 prepayment was $7,709.00 . The remaining should be closer to $3,855 . For Washington, $183.94 is attributed to WA's B&O (gross receipts) tax, due when filing returns but not collected from customers. The other states' differences are minor and within the % margin for rounding, timely filing discounts, and other state-specific tax logic. We weren't able to account for refunds that caused negative amounts in local jurisdictions in the past, but we are still tracking this and plan to work that into the May 2025 filing for April 2025. Please let me know if you have any questions. We're still working towards getting this data to you earlier in the month, but we have had some unexpected delays in the last few weeks. I'm also happy to hop on a call if you have any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Aleli, Thanks for the question and your patience here! Can you share the process on how you exclude sales though Shop? Sure! Our Engineering Team has implemented measures to account for Marketplace sales through Shopify's Shop app. These measures detect these transactions using Shopify App ID values provided in Shopify's Admin API Orders endpoint data. Our Shopify integration can detect this when your store's transactions sync with Zamp. Zamp will then file the sales tax returns associated with the Shopify transactions where Shopify does not collect sales tax as a marketplace. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any additional questions.

author: adewberry@zamp.com

author: aleli@warrenjames.org
body: That's good to know! Can you share the process on how you exclude sales though Shop?

author: adewberry@zamp.com
body: Hi Aleli, Thanks for reaching out! Shopify is acting as the marketplace facilitator for Shop sales. This means that any transactions through Shop, you will not be responsible for collecting and remitting this tax, because Shopify is handling that for those transactions. This is handled appropriately on our end and no further action is required by you. Please let me know if you would like to discuss this further. I'm happy to jump on a call. Feel free to schedule a time that works best for you here . Thanks, Ashley

We'll use this for reference regarding Shopify vs Zamp filing: https://3.basecamp.com/5828705/buckets/39340745/documents/8350965793 Hi Aleli, On the current plan you have with Shopify, Shopify is not remitting or filing the sales tax returns for you. author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Nicole, You're welcome; thanks for reaching out! Christine let me know that you called, but I was on a call at that time. I'll answer your questions below, and I'm happy to hop on a call sometime if that would be helpful. What I thought was happening is that we overpaid sales tax at the beginning so this was the credits being applied. Is this correct? Yes‚Äîthis is correct! There were duplicate transactions between a manual CSV import and a QuickBooks Online integration. If so, why are we not taking the full credit for the amount owed each period? Or is it something different? The plan we discussed previously (correct me if I'm wrong, Sadh) is that we would adjust for 10% of the overpaid sales tax each month to prevent sudden changes in Gross Sales and Tax Due amounts from month to month. Another reason here is that some states don't have a tax due amount when we're filing or a filing is not due. I hope this helps!

If so, why are we not taking the full credit for the amount owed each period? Or is it something different? This is my reconciliation right now with QuickBooks and I mainly want to be sure I know what is happening with CA. Best, Nicole

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Paul, Great question; thanks for working with us here! As a follow up, what is the cadence of these returns? Sure! Our typical timeline and process (including deadlines) are: We'll send out a request for the CSV data between the 1st and 3rd of the month. We aim to have all CSV sales data by the 6th of each month. We aim to approve all sales tax returns by the 10th of each month (by clicking a button or automatically releasing them by the noted date in our tax-due estimate email). We can be somewhat flexible with the above, especially if there are questions or concerns. Our focus is ensuring timely filing, maximizing timely filing discounts across various states, and efficiency within our teams. I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Liz, Thanks for sharing this with us! We'll need to investigate further, but we'll likely want to disconnect the current Amazon integration with Zamp because we have that sales data syncing separately. If the Amazon data flows into Shopify, we won't need the Amazon connection, as Zamp will handle the transactions from either source. Within Zamp, we'll always view transactions from Amazon (either the direct integration or Shopify) as $0 tax to ensure that tax is not remitted twice because Amazon collects and remits as a marketplace facilitator. The good news is that this won't cause any tax duplication but may cause duplicate amounts within Pacagen's Gross Sales amounts. However, we can quickly help sort that out. A few questions: 1) Do we know when this change was made to bring Amazon transactions into Shopify? Was it effective on 4/8/2025? 2) Was this change applied to historical (before X date) data in any way? 3) Could you or the team share examples of Shopify Order IDs synced to Shopify from Amazon? I've found a few, but I'd like to be sure. The examples I found are: #37965 #37961 #37911

After that, we can generate a tax-due estimate and get the filings moving. Just so that you know, the Shopify integration allows the process to be automated. Still, we're also happy to handle it this way if Odoo is the source of truth‚Äîthis is the preference here‚Äîor if importing the data from Odoo instead simplifies reconciliation processes for you all.

body: Hi Chris, I believe there may have been some miscommunication between us and Zamp. I've reattached the sales figures for Joolca Inc. for March 2025 (this includes both B2B and B2C customers). Just a quick clarification on the data: all our transaction IDs start with INV , and credit notes begin with RINV . Looking at the file you have on hand, I noticed that by row 1163, the transaction IDs appear to have changed to numerical values only. I suspect these might be transactions pulled directly from Shopify? To confirm from our end, we use Odoo as our source of truth. The Excel spreadsheet I've provided is extracted directly from Odoo, so there's no need to pull data from Shopify. Does the above make sense, or would you like me to clarify anything further? Regards Ching

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Ching, Thanks for the response here; we're happy to help. As requested, we've held Joolca's filings until we have your approval to proceed. Just so you know, we will need to hear back with approval to file by the end of the day (EST) on Friday, April 11th, 2025 , for Zamp to be able to process your filings timely this month. A few states, such as Maine (with a 4/15 due date) and Michigan (for the timely filing discount), have earlier due dates or timelines. I've attached two XLSX files containing the transaction data Zamp used to build these tax-due estimates. Each file includes a sheet showing the tax total per state and overall. The combined tax total across all monthly and quarterly states with due dates this month is $62,015.96 . It's important to note that the Washington March 2025 filing and estimate also include a WA B&O tax (gross receipts tax) filed with the sales tax return; this amount is $342.40 . In addition to the above, Zamp's tax-due estimates have various state-specific logic in place for handling time zones, rounding, and timely filing discounts; we share some details about this here (also here ). I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions.

NY is quarterly prepay, so we file the monthly tax collected amount. California: This one is also a quarterly prepay. Jan 25 prepayment: 7,444.09 Feb 25 prepayment: 11,741.93 Total: 19,186.02 Remaining: $8,940.98 The notice was sent here: https://secure.helpscout.net/conversation/2893756326

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Great; we'll look forward to speaking with you tomorrow! What report am I supposed to be looking at? and what report do you use? This is a tricky question to answer, but generally, the Shopify US Taxes report you shared is the better report to start with. That being said, there will almost always be some differences (usually 1-2% but under 5%) between Shopify and Zamp; we share more information about that in this article . The differences are usually caused by rounding, timely filing discounts, or differences in time zone handling (Zamp adjusts for each state's specific time zone). Zamp doesn't use a Shopify Report to build our filings and ingest sales data because we use the data provided by Shopify's API. If we need to reference something in Shopify for a tax-related report, we will generally look at the US Taxes Report. When did you loose access to the Shopify store? Thanks for the access code! I just sent a request over. Unfortunately, we're unsure when the access was lost because Shopify hasn't shown us the date. This is an access that can auto-expire after 90-days. We've started some conversations with our engineering team to find ways to prevent this from happening. The good news is that this only affects our ability to view your Shopify store and doesn't affect Zamp syncing your sales data for filing purposes. I'm still reviewing the situation here but should have more detail before our call tomorrow.

author: patrick@nisolo.com
body:
Christine, Chris, & Team,

Good morning and happy Monday! I am following up with a few important updates for Zamp related to the tax filings for March transactions. Here are important updates: Now that I understand that Zamp cannot close states for Nisolo, I've updated the "Actions Needed by Zamp" direction by state in column D of the attached spreadsheet, titled "4.7.25 Update to 4.2.25 Copy March Transactions Zamp Nisolo Follow Up Direction By State" and the updates can be seen on the "2.0 Revised‚Ä¶" tab. There are 10 states that we need for Zamp to take action on. These 10 states are listed at the top of the "2.0 Revised‚Ä¶" tab in the spreadsheet. Reuben & I will focus on closing all of the others in green without Zamp support given Zamp cannot help close the states. For the 5 states that need past taxes paid for, refer to the tab "Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" for the total amount owed in each state. Also, note that the "Order Data" requested by Chris for each state for the relevant time ranges where we found past collected tax have all been attached to this email as hard copies, which show the orders within each individual state. Also attached to this email is a spreadsheet that shows all historical sales and taxes collected by month by year for each state (this is the sales data, not the individual orders) I tried to highlight on each tab in teal any states where there was unpaid, collected tax, and I do not think you'll need this spreadsheet. However, note that the "Prior tax to be paid" in column B on the "Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" tab of the "4.7.25 Update‚Ä¶" spreadsheet corresponds with the data from the "Shopify Sales by Month 2019 by Shipping Region sales_2019-01-01_2019-12-31 (1)" spreadsheet. This data in Column B is what we want to make sure gets paid by state in the March transaction filings. Note, there is a discrepancy between the totals in that spreadsheet vs. what you would find in each individual state (order data) spreadsheets, I believe bc one set of tax is Net of Returns and the other is Gross of Returns. For further clarity on the discrepancy, please note the following, which is also outlined on the ""Collected Tax Dates & Ranges" tab: Even though the date range used is the exact same, there is a discrepancy in total tax owed (Ex Nevada $12K vs. $18K) in the individual state spreadsheet data of "Orders" (column E or see hardcopy) vs. the (Column D or hardcopy) "Shopify Sales by Month 2019 by Shipping Region sales_2019-01-01_2019-12-31 (1)" file, we believe because Column E "Orders" is GROSS of returns but the other Column D is Net of returns. Nisolo has had around a 25-30% Return rate historically. Again, the spreadsheet hosting only the individual state's info (column E or in hardcopy) is GROSS of returns, and returns have not been taken out, and therefore tax is higher. Again, the "Shopify Sales by Month" spreadsheet (Column D or hardcopy) is Net sales with tax NET of returns, and therefore is the more accurate reading of tax owed that needs to be paid. Chris, once you have a chance to review this material, please let me know if you have any questions or if this gives you all that you need for Zamp to ensure the past collected tax gets filed on time for March transactions so that we can pay it and close the states on time. Thank you! Patrick

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rachel, Thanks for sending the file over and for these great questions! On the Shopify transactions, can you please clarify how that works with Shopify now remitting some of the taxes for us? It looks like they may not be remitting all of it? Sure! To our understanding, Shopify is now remitting any taxes collected through the 'SHOP' channel, which is tied into a specific payment method and marketplace via the Shop app (I believe this is an Android and iPhone app). They won't remit taxes collected from an order placed on BetterWild's website. This means that shop payments or channel orders can still come through with tax that BetterWild would need to remit via Zamp's filings. A way to see this could be using this Shopify report and adding a filter for 'Filed' under 'Filed by channel' like this: How are you handling those transactions? Our Engineering Team has already implemented measures to account for Marketplace sales through Shopify Shop. You will not be remitting taxes that Shopify has already remitted. Our Shopify integration can detect this when your store's transactions sync with Zamp. Zamp will then file the sales tax returns associated with the other transactions. I hope this helps!

author: rachel@betterwild.com
body: See attached for the CSV file for non-Shopify transactions. On the Shopify transactions, can you please clarify how that works with Shopify now remitting some of the taxes for us? It looks like they may not be remitting all of it? How are you handling those transactions? Thanks, Rachel

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Henry, Thanks again for your time today and your partnership! Regarding the partial refunds and manually edited orders: Starting this month (or soon), for the filings that will be processed in June, we discussed using a CSV template (imported into Google Sheets) that follows Zamp's import template (attached). We will share how to prepare that file in this article . For the April 2025 transactions, I'll run our "forced" Shopify reconciliation script. Regarding editing orders within Loop instead of Shopify: This change would likely involve multiple pieces, and I hope the information below is helpful. Here are some Loop resources that I found about this, and it may be worth triple-checking for best practices from the Loop Support Team: Create a Return for a Customer Return Policy Settings Variant Exchange Different Priced Exchanges Advanced Exchanges Regarding outstanding state-specific items: I've also contacted Amelia about the outstanding items for any remaining states. While researching it a bit, I found that Amelia shared these outstanding items on 4/8/25 at 9:53 AM EST and followed up on 4/28/25 at 12:41 PM EST; the subject of that email was ' Re: Onboarding Call Follow up with Zamp '. I'm sharing this if it helps find the email, but Amelia will follow up as soon as possible. Here's what Amelia shared. I recommend directing any registration/account/state questions about this to Amelia or onboarding@zamp.com (if you have questions before Amelia reaches out). Great! Here is the list of states, contact details, and what we need to be able to file. Missouri - We still need to get the responsible party date of birth and ssn/itin of the person used at the time of registering in Missouri. 573-751-5860 North Carolina- Since there is no apparent registration id number outside of the SST number, you will need to call the state so they can advise steps needed - is the account is still open, next steps based on your current status, etc. You can ask them what is required by you to start filing online via non-SST or if a new registration is needed. NC contact number- 877-252-3052 Nevada- Since the login provided is not the master account login, you will need to call the state and they can advise/update the access to ensure your login is set as an administrator. Nevada contact number - 866-962-3707 Please let me know if you need any clarifications or have any questions on this. Please let me know if you or your team have any questions about the Loop Discount or the other items we discussed. We are aiming to have a tax-due estimate sent your way by Monday or Tuesday next week, after adjusting for the Shopify variances. Have a wonderful weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Notes: Causes of the differences: They don't have the loop discount turned on. They manually edit orders if a customer calls or emails in, but they don't do that in Loop; it's within Shopify. They sometimes issue partial refunds for issues, discounts, promos, leaving reviews, etc., which ties into Shopify's limitations around partial refunds, which do not account for tax. They already track order edits and partial refunds internally, and can ask the team to enter that into a CSV or in a way that it can be put into a CSV (A Google Sheet most likely.) Henry will: Ask about: loop discount editing orders in Loop This is a process change that will take some time. Tracking partial refunds. The above items will likely start this month for filing in June. For the April 2025 filing, we'll use the Shopify forced reconciliation script. My action items: Ask Amelia to give Henry an update and ask for any action items. Send the CSV article and template, for order edit and partial refunds to be shared with Zamp (for May and onward, until Zamp engineering has something in place and/or the Mod Lighting Team can edit orders in Loop.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, One more follow-up as we head into the weekend! Aside from the two previously missing Shopify transactions, we found that there were some slight variances between Zamp's tax collected and Shopify's due to the manual workaround method we used here. Outside of the above, the difference was caused by the two missing transactions and what appears to be some rounding in Shopify's US tax reporting. Would you have time to discuss this and the plan to resolve it as we move forward next week?

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, You're welcome! Regarding the variance between Shopify and Zamp: We're still reviewing some Shopify reports, such as the Q1 2025 Texas Transactions Report , to determine why this difference exists. Part of what we've discovered happened here is that when we used the manual workaround method to import your Shopify data, the two transactions below were missed. CE1005X CE1004X We're still working through comparing the tax amounts between transactions in Zamp and transactions in Shopify to find the remaining difference. This is a piece that should be confirmed by tomorrow. This situation is something that we will help correct and ensure doesn't happen again in the future. If you have some time sometime soon, we'd be happy to hop on a call to talk about this and the path to resolving it. Regarding the Eventbrite transactions: This part of the import process was missed, and we've already taken steps to ensure it doesn't happen again, including adding additional reminders on our end. The good news here is that Eventbrite, as a marketplace , remits the taxes it collects to the state of Texas and other states listed in their article here . This means that while we do still want to import these transactions and report the gross sales to TX , your business doesn't need to remit the tax (Zamp includes this as a 'Marketplace Facilitator deduction' on filings.) When we create these kinds of transactions in Zamp, we do so with $0 tax collected to ensure Dandy Lion doesn't pay the tax twice. Regarding the Amazon transactions: I've found that Amazon transactions did not sync over to Zamp, but I've been unable to find any errors associated with this issue. I'm checking in with Amelia about a couple of items here in the morning. We can take an approach of having our team manually download these transactions each month to ensure they are accounted for as Marketplace Facilitator transactions, similar to Eventbrite. For Amazon and Eventbrite transactions, we can include them in a future filing, such as the Q2 2025 tax filing. We're also happy to discuss this on a call if you'd prefer. We're here to help resolve this and ensure Dandy Lion is compliant; fix these data situations.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jessica, Thanks for the response and the direct feedback. We understand where you're coming from with this and will be sure to improve. We're also happy to hop on a call to discuss this, after we've confirmed what happened. The reason this was a one-time exception and the cause of the difference is related to the email Amelia sent out a bit ago regarding your Shopify store's Shopify subscription and recent limitations implemented by Shopify. The Shopify changes caused Zamp to be unable to import all of your Shopify transactions, so we imported them manually using a workaround. I'm re-investigating the differences between the Shopify report and Zamp; I am also investigating what happened with the Eventbrite sales and Amazon sales. Please note that Amazon and Eventbrite both collect and remit (file) sales taxes in Texas and many other states as a Marketplace Facilitator. Meaning‚Äîthose taxes are already paid to the state, and Dandy Lion LLC won't need to pay those taxes to the state, but each state (including TX) has reporting requirements for sellers. We share more information in this guide . I'll have an update for you about this today!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Carol, Thanks for the response! Why would we need to know zipcode as these are exempt transactions? Zamp needs the zip code because our system is designed to bucket all transactions into specific local jurisdictions within a US state. (Without it, we are unable to import the transaction data.) That process happens by having either of the below combinations of shipping address data. The shipping city and state. The shipping zip code. Additionally, for some US state sales tax filings, the state Department of Revenue(s) requires a breakdown of wholesale transactions by the local jurisdiction in addition to the state-level tax-exempt amount.

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience. The small difference between your Shopify and Zamp tax reports comes from two main factors: Rounding differences in calculations and per state rules Time zone settings (your Shopify store uses EST, while Zamp uses each state capital's time zone for remittance) Good news! We've just launched a feature that lets you view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. To better compare Zamp transactions to your Shopify store's EST setting, check your March 2025 report in US/Eastern time: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern For more details, see our article: " Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices " Let me know if this helps clarify things!

author: carie@zamp.com
body: Hi @lucas - great draft! I made a few minor changes below. I went ahead and bolded the changes so you could easily see them but please unbold before sending! Also, please confirm that my comments are correct. ;) I also included a more simplified version below, which might be a good alternative but either way! ‚Äî- Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience here. The slight difference between the reports is primarily due to rounding (related to calculations and state rules) and time zones. Shopify uses a standard time zone across all orders, while Zamp assigns each order to the timezone of the state capital where it's remitted . We explain this in more detail in our article: "Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices" . In the case of your Shopify store, it is set to EST timezone. We recently launched a new feature allowing you to view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. Take a look at how your March-2025 report would appear in US/Eastern: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern . This should further align with the timezone settings in your Shopify store and the transactions associated with March 2025. Let me know if exploring this feature helps clarify things! ‚Äî Hey Dante, Thanks for your patience. The small difference between your Shopify and Zamp tax reports comes from two main factors: Rounding differences in calculations and per state rules Time zone settings (your Shopify store uses EST, while Zamp uses each state capital's time zone for remittance) Good news! We've just launched a feature that lets you view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. To better compare Zamp transactions to your Shopify store's EST setting, check your March 2025 report in US/Eastern time: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern For more details, see our article: " Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices " Let me know if this helps clarify things!

author: landrade@zamp.com
body:
Hey, @carie I'd like your help here. I'd like assistance in formulating a response to the customer regarding the discrepancy they've observed between their filing and the Shopify report. The difference is less than 1%, and this can largely be attributed to rounding and time zones. I‚Äôve also identified that the customer uses the Order Editing app, which will necessitate further investigation on our part. To ensure appropriate handling of this matter, I intend to focus my initial response on the rounding/timezone issue, deferring discussion regarding the third-party app until an alignment with Chris. Below is the message I intend to send. "Hey Dante,
Thanks for your patience here. The slight difference between the reports is primarily due to rounding (related to calculations and state rules) and time zones. Shopify uses a standard time zone across all orders, while Zamp assigns each order to the timezone of the state capital where it's shipped ‚Äì this reflects how states expect sales tax reports to be formatted. We explain this in more detail in our article: "Understanding Discrepancies Between Shopify and Zamp Filing Notices" . We recently launched a new feature allowing you to view your Tax Collected report in different time zones. Take a look at how your March/2025 report would appear in US/Eastern: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31&timezone=US/Eastern Let me know if exploring this feature helps clarify things!"

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: Overall It looks like variances in this case are caused by a combination of rounding, time zone, and order editing. Both reports (US Sales Tax and Zamp Tax Collected) match, in about 80% of the cases, when using the same timezone. The customer can check this with the new 'timezone' feature in the Tax Collected report and the Transactions page in our product. Below is the comparison ( https://admin.zamp.com/companies/cm0fqv7yz00mkplgno37indzk/customer-reports/taxes-collected?timezone=US/Eastern ) There are also a couple of orders with different tax values collected, some of which were edited via the Order Editing third-party app ( https://admin.shopify.com/store/officialkittyfountain/orders/6146588934364?link_source=search ), and some were simply not collected ( https://admin.shopify.com/store/officialkittyfountain/orders/6142193369308?link_source=search ). I also found that there is no tax collected in DC in US Sales Tax Report Here is the summary table with all my findings: state total_tax_transactions total_tax_us_tax_report total_tax_missing_from us_tax_report total_tax_order_editing_diff final_abs_diff final_pct_diff AK 18.83 17.57 1.26 0 0.04 0.21% AR 341.68 341.68 0 0 0 0.00% AZ 1202.72 1211.15 -8.43 0 0.03 0.00% CA 16149.81 16048.65 5.41 94.73 1.06 0.01% CO 1549.01 1539.77 0 11.28 -2.08 -0.13% DC 77.06 77.06 0 -77.06 -100.00% FL 7976.74 7948.18 0 25.72 2.88 0.04% GA 1257.4 1241.8 6.8 12.4 -3.6 -0.29% IL 2257.31 2241.19 0 15.53 0.57 0.03% MD 1973.54 1958.63 0 14.91 -0.01 0.00% NC 3946.51 3933.69 0 11.59 1.21 0.03% NJ 3025.33 3001.81 0 22.87 0.63 0.02% NV 1340.48 1332.11 2.01 6.68 -0.29 -0.02% PA 5635.83 5609.13 0 25.22 1.48 0.03% RI 161.29 160.74 0 0.55 -0.05 -0.03% VA 1068.98 1064.79 0 3.13 1.07 0.10% VT 569.99 553.39 0 16.6 0 0.00% WA 5812.99 5767.52 2.48 42.14 0.88 0.02% WV 261.02 261.02 0 0 0 0.00% TOTAL 54626.52 54232.82 86.59 303.35 -73.24 -0.13% US Sales Tax Report vs. Zamp Transactions Overall, the report matches, especially when using the same timezone, but below is a comparison between the two, each one using their timezone settings. We can see that the differences are small, less than 1% in most cases, and 0.6% in the overall scenario. It would also be important to get the cause of the variances between transactions, which is equal to the Tax Collected report. and the filing report state total_tax_transactions total_tax_us_tax_report abs_diff pct_diff AK 18.83 17.57 1.3 6.9% AR 341.68 341.68 0 0.0% AZ 1202.72 1211.15 -8.4 -0.7% CA 16149.81 16048.65 101.2 0.6% CO 1549.01 1539.77 9.2 0.6% DC 77.06 0 77.06 100% FL 7976.74 7948.18 28.6 0.4% GA 1257.4 1241.8 15.6 1.2% IL 2257.31 2241.19 16.1 0.7% MD 1973.54 1958.63 14.9 0.8% NC 3946.51 3933.69 12.8 0.3% NJ 3025.33 3001.81 23.5 0.8% NV 1340.48 1332.11 8.4 0.6% PA 5635.83 5609.13 26.7 0.5% RI 161.29 160.74 0.5 0.3% VA 1068.98 1064.79 4.2 0.4% VT 569.99 553.39 16.6 2.9% WA 5812.99 5767.52 45.5 0.8% WV 261.02 261.02 0 0.0% TOTAL 54626.52 54232.82 316.7 0.6% Missing Transactions I found 2056 orders missing from the US Sales Tax Report, and the majority of them are due to time zone differences settings Below is a state-grouped tax report of these missing transactions state total_tax AK 1.26 AR 0 AZ -8.43 CA 5.41 CO 0 DC 77.06 FL 0 GA 6.8 IL 0 MD 0 NC 0 NJ 0 NV 2.01 PA 0 RI 0 VA 0 VT 0 WA 2.48 WV 0 Order Editing Therefore, the majority variances can be explained by timezone differences; some of them are due to other reasons, like the Order Editing third-party app. Below is a state summary of the differences between how much Zamp Transactions got as tax collected and the US Sales Tax report state_abbreviation tax_diff CA 94.73 CO 11.28 FL 25.72 GA 12.4 IL 15.53 MD 14.91 NC 11.59 NJ 22.87 NV 6.68 PA 25.22 RI 0.55 VA 3.13 VT 16.6 WA 42.14 Takeaways The variances in this case are small, less than 1% Rounding and time zone can explain most of the cases, and the new 'timezone' feature can help to evidence it Tax Collected report and Filing report are different, which I believe is due to rounding and/or state tax rules. They use Order Editing third-party app, so we should map this customer and add an offset import step to the import workflow, such as Ghost Golf.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Dante, Thanks for reaching out! We will investigate this further and should have more details to share next week. Please note that there are some common reasons for differences between Zamp's tax due estimate and Shopify's reporting, such as time zone differences, rounding, or timely filing discounts; we discuss these in more detail in this article . Also, our understanding is that Shopify separates the tax amount you'll see in Zamp's estimates into two categories, and this means Zamp's tax-due estimate is a combination of these values for each state: total_item_tax_amount total_shipping_tax_amount I hope this helps!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger and Team, Thanks so much for your patience and understanding here. A colleague and I investigated this situation and found the following details; please let us know if you have any questions. Regarding the more minor differences: Zamp's tax-due estimate aligns closely with Shopify's US Sales Tax report when adjusting for time zones, timely filing discounts, state-specific rounding, etc; these variances are usually below 5%. The amounts in this Shopify US Sales Tax Report differ from the original list for various states. If you used this Report previously, it's possible it wasn't yet up-to-date, as I'm unsure how often these reports update in Shopify. In general, the differences noted here are mainly due to Zamp's adjustments to file based on each state's specific time zone, while Shopify uses a single time zone. In our article here , we discuss more of the differences noted above and other common differences between Zamp and Shopify. When I filter the Shopify US Sales Tax Report for the states filed monthly and then separately for the states filed quarterly while expanding the date range and summing the tax totals, it is within $78 of Zamp's estimate. Regarding Texas: The above includes Texas because the Shopify US Sales Tax report for TX and an example of the time zone differences here is the order noted below. When adjusting for the CST time zone, Order ID OB48264 in Zamp is reported as 3/1/25, but in Shopify, it's listed with a date of 2/28/25. The Shopify US Sales Tax report shows $1,075.59 in tax collected, which is $63.84 less than Zamp's total, which was recently updated to 1,139.43 (or 5.94%). We couldn't find any missing or extra transactions, and the tax amounts aligned with Shopify. I've also attached an export of the transactions Zamp is using to determine the tax due. I hope this is helpful to you. Please let us know if you have any questions. We'll need to move the filings along into the process by the end of the day tomorrow, April 15th, 2025 , to file by the state's due dates and avoid any penalties and interest. Do you approve of proceeding with One Bed's filings this month?

author: chris@zamp.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Rodger, Thanks for the response and for sharing these details! Regarding California: Yes‚Äîthis is happening because Zamp's understanding per One Bed's CA sales tax registration is that the filing frequency is what we call 'Quarterly Prepay,' which aligns with CA's pay monthly and file quarterly filing frequency. This does equal the monthly sales tax due in most scenarios, and we hope to improve our tax-due estimates in the future. We'll triple-check this and share that confirmation in our follow-up. Regarding the large difference you noted for Texas: This is interesting to hear. I have a few questions to help us understand why there is such a difference and the potential causes. 1) Does One Bed use third-party apps for returns/exchanges, such as Loop? 2) Does One Bed use third-party apps to allow customers to edit their orders after placing them? Is that done manually by the One Bed Team or at all? 3) Could you please confirm by sharing a screenshot or an export of the Shopify Report that you're reviewing and comparing against Zamp? 4) When you have a moment, could you please share One Bed's Collaborator request code with us? This will allow us to request access to your Shopify store again because that access expired automatically according to Shopify's policy. This should be under Settings ‚Äî> Users ‚Äî> Security.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hello, Chloe and Camille, Thanks once again for your patience while we investigated the various situations here. Regarding California: This Fortunate One difference is similar to Hello Molly. This difference happens because Fortunate One makes monthly prepayments to CA and a quarterly filing (a quarterly prepay filing frequency). Here's a breakdown of this for Fortunate One: The January 2025 prepayment was $2,964.38 . The February 2025 prepayment was $4,161.28 . Total prepayments: $7,125.66 . Remaining tax-due estimate: $7,030.88 Combined total: $14,156.54 . Regarding the remaining states brought up here: The following states have different filing frequencies that are either annual or a non-standard quarter: Indiana has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. Nebraska has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. New York has a quarterly filing frequency, but this is within the fiscal quarter date range , so the next return is the NY Q1 2025 return, due in June 2025. Texas: To our understanding, Fortunate One is not currently registered for a sales tax permit or account in Texas. It's possible that the tax was accidentally collected within Shopify if someone accidentally turned it on previously. Still, it does not appear to be enabled currently, as we do not see any tax collection in TX. We'd recommend refunding the tax to the customer if tax were accidentally collected. This can happen when tax is collected on an order, and the address is later changed. If you know the Order ID associated with that order, we can investigate it further within Zamp. We've seen this happen with other companies we work with ( this Shopify community thread has some details), but we do not currently know a solution. We'd recommend that you check with Shopify support about the options here. A follow-up question: Considering the details noted above, do you know if we have your approval to proceed with Fortunate One's filings this month? Once you're ready for us to file, you can also click the blue ' Review & approve filings ' button. Otherwise and if we don't hear back about this, we'll resume filing by Thursday, April 10th, 2025 , to ensure timely filings. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: California This difference is due to quarterly prepay. January 2025 prepayment: $2,964.38 February 2025 prepayment: $4,161.28 Total: $7,125.66 Remaining: $7,030.88 We also see a total of $14k. Additional states: Indiana has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. Nebraska has an annual filing frequency, and the subsequent filing would be in January 2026. New York is quarterly with a fiscal quarter date range, so the next return is the NY Q1 2025 return, which is due in June 2025. Texas‚ÄîOn Zamp's side, Texas was not included because we understand that Fortunate One is not registered to collect sales taxes in Texas. This can happen with Shopify orders if the address is changed after the order is placed or if tax collection was accidentally turned on for TX at some point.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Kevin, You're welcome! For the states where we have sales tax, can you please confirm that those states tax sales of food products? Of course! So that you know, the taxability of food will vary from state to state and from one product category (type/tax code) to another. To our understanding, the 'Nutrition Bars' category would be taxed in all those states except for those noted below. Washington D.C. ‚ÄîThis is a small amount, and it could be leftover from the various product category changes you have been working on. Vermont ‚ÄîThis is a small amount that could be related to the items noted for DC (above). Washington ‚ÄîThe tax estimate here is mainly due to WA's Business & Occupation tax , a gross receipts tax not collected from customers but due when filing a sales tax return; the remainder could be similar to the two states noted above. The WA B&O tax amount is $461.35. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: kevin@eatmezcla.com
body: Thanks Nick! For the states where we have sales tax, can you please confirm that those states tax sales of food products?

body: Hi Sean, Thanks for taking the time to discuss this with me earlier! I've attached a spreadsheet showing the GameFound invoices in North Carolina. There, we see under-collection at the state rate of 4.75%; those examples are highlighted in light blue. Two transactions (rows) are highlighted in light green, and those two had the correct amount of tax collected: 6594902 6538249 I simplified the GameFound file to the state, city, zip code, Order IDs, Order Code, Project ID, and amounts. Regarding Virginia: I am investigating what happened with Order ID 6793221, and we will include it in the May 2025 filing period to ensure the tax is remitted. Please let me know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Confirmed: the difference here is due to Magic Math /Grossing Down, which is happening due to under-collecting sales tax. VA notice: System failed to calculate 1 transaction(s) totaling $118.91, so they were excluded. One transaction was missing: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clr6g73v20006a8lippj6yh3a/transactions?date=2025-03-01%7E2025-03-31&shipToState=VA&limit=100 . It's this transaction: https://admin.zamp.com/companies/clr6g73v20006a8lippj6yh3a/transactions/cm9bh5suy000ljo04j8snqfv8?timezone=US/Local&shipToState=VA&date=2025-03-01~2025-03-31 . These NC transactions had the right amount of tax collected: 6538249 - 6594902 The rest of them had under collection that appeared to include only the state rate of 4.75%. Sean will check with the business owner to see if they want to pay the under-collected tax out of pocket; he'll follow up to let us know. I'm providing Sean with the under-collected NC Transactions so that he can contact their rep at GameFound (their sales platform) to see what can be done about this moving forward.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Sean, Thanks again for being so patient here! We've been investigating this and have found that it appears related to how the CSV was imported and how Zamp ensures only the tax collected is filed. We still have a few items to investigate and test, but it is best to schedule a call sometime next week to discuss this further. I hope that you have a great weekend!

author: landrade@zamp.com
body: @chris I'm working on it and want to share my findings and thoughts. There is no difference between the customer file and Zamp transactions. I believe the variance is related to the magic math. CSVs comparison There is no difference in the tax total, subtotal, and transaction total between the customer CSV file and the transactions in Zamp. I noticed some inconsistencies in some shipping states. When comparing either CustomerSubLocationIsoCode or ShippingSubLocationIsoCode from the customer file to the shiptoState from Zamp, a few of them don't match. However, they have the same zip code in both files, so I believe we're fine in terms of reporting. Magic Math When checking the variance review export and filtering by sectionName equal to 'General State' (the filing section where the gross sales were reduced), we see the exact amount used to file in the taxableAmount (NC = 2987.37) Question: Why was the gross sales amount reduced, but the tax due/ collected remains the same?

author: slabbe@earthbornegames.com
body: Hi Nick, So the problem with Gamefound is that transactions are not dated and changes are not logged. So there's no way to retroactively find the date of the transaction being finalized. So what I'm doing is running the gamefound report on the last day of the month. When I run the one for April, it will also include everything for March. Which means I'll have to reverse out all the March activity from the April report based on what I recognize in March before I send it to you. It's a pretty big hassle, but BackerKit worked the same way! So I think I would just date everything for the last day of the month, unless you see a reason to do it differently.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Belva, Thanks for the response!! OK, great! We will get the WV invoice 11490 voided, as that will be faster on our end (instead of waiting for a delete request), and that should allow me to send you the updated amounts tonight. Regarding Washington: The difference here is due to WA's B&O tax . The B&O Retailing tax is $870.21 for Q1 2025, including the possible duplicate invoice 11328. Once we remove invoice 11328, the B&O tax amount will decrease because it is a gross receipts tax calculated by multiplying the Gross Sales by 0.471%. After removing this duplicate invoice, a rough estimate shows that the B&O tax should be about $465.41 , and the overall tax should be closer to an estimate of $10,823.47. Considering the above, should we void or delete WA invoice 11328?

author: bzmerzlikar@compliatric.com

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Belva, A quick follow-up here! I believe I found the issue, and it appears that this may be related to two deleted invoices as that no longer exist in QuickBooks Online: For West Virginia , we have an invoice 11490 in Zamp that no longer appears in QBO with a tax amount of $193.11. For Washington , we have invoice 11328 in Zamp that no longer appears in QBO. Its tax amount is $7,742.08, and it appears to be a duplicate of invoice 11444 . I've attached an XLSX file showing the exports from Zamp and their comparisons to see if the invoice number exists in the QBO export and if there are any differences in the tax collected. The tax collected amounts match, within reason for rounding, but two Zamp invoices appear "extra." Do you think we should ask our engineering team to proceed with deleting invoices 11490 and 11328?

body: Hello Aman, Ian, and Team, I just wanted to follow up quickly! Regarding the tax-due estimate: The tax-due estimate sent a little while ago can be ignored. There was a mistake in sending it, but we've resolved the root cause. We're working on regenerating the estimate using the March 2025 filing periods, and we appreciate your patience. Regarding your questions: what is the total amount, and when is the latest we can file? We'll send you an updated total amount in the next few minutes. The total is listed at the bottom of the email following ' Estimated sales tax this month: ' The latest we can wait to file this month (as an exception and due to our partnership) is next Thursday, 4/10/2025. Also do you still need / collect wholesale information to reduce the liability? Yes, we do need Wholesale transactions from you if those don't occur through Shopify. If your customers are marked as tax-exempt in Shopify, we'll capture that as well. Please note that, generally, wholesale/resale transactions won't reduce the liability here because sales tax is not collected on them. If tax was collected on a transaction and later refunded due to being wholesale or resale, please let us know and share the Order ID/number; we can help update that within Zamp. We value your partnership and thank you for your understanding. Please feel free to contact us with any questions.

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Bill, Thanks! I hope you're also doing well and appreciate your patience! We're both pretty busy, and I'm glad we are on the same page. We appreciate your patience while we worked through some technical hiccups (unrelated to this situation) yesterday and today. This makes sense to me, and after digging into QuickBooks Online's various articles and forums further, I'm seeing what you're saying and found the pattern where it appears currency conversions don't always work with foreign amounts, etc. Can we include the 'Exchange Rate' available in this custom QBO Report export and utilize that as a temporary workaround for part of the process? Our upcoming significant QBO integration release will help resolve much of this and increase accuracy. I've attached a file as an example. The exchange rate is usually 1.34 or 1.35 in this file. We would do this after filtering out non-US 'Bill To' addresses. I'm still happy to have a call to discuss this or any filing/data/QBO-related questions you might have. I'll be around until ~8:00 PM EST today, and have quite a bit of availability next week.

author: bill.lin@lumiqlearn.com
body:
Hi Chris,

I hope you're doing well! Thanks for your patience.

To answer your questions: 1) We do have a small batch of US customers who actually do request to be billed in CAD. Oftentimes it has to do with three reasons: (1) they have a Canadian CPA employee, or (2) they hold some CAD for FX hedging. Unfortunately, those ones won't have a USD amount inherently - the two possible solutions here would just be to: Accept that the foreign amount is in CAD but just say it's in USD for nexus analysis - it's such a small batch of customers with small amounts that if that's the reason we hit nexus we were going to hit nexus next month Find an average FX rate to convert them at in order to get to the final amount 2) The foreign amount in Quickbooks is the amount in the invoice currency (so typically a US customer's foreign amount will be in USD). Now here's the issue - the tax amount and the net amount are ALWAYS in CAD in Quickbooks and we haven't identified a field that shows those amounts in the invoice currency.

Let me know if you wanna hop on a call to find a workaround or discuss any of this as tomorrow we can definitely make some time!

Cheers,

Bill

Should we ignore those invoices, or is there a way (that you know of) to export them in USD from QuickBooks Online (QBO)? 2) How are the foreign amount, tax, and net amounts configured within QBO? My goal here is to ensure an accurate and scalable solution in the long term for filing LumiQ's US state sales tax returns accurately. We're almost there! We can also schedule a quick call using this link if you'd prefer to discuss that way!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason, Thanks for the input here; I understand. Yes, I'm positive it's related to negative amounts in specific jurisdictions because the negative amounts line up with the differences. This scenario can happen anytime the two conditions below are met, and my understanding is that Zamp has behaved this way the whole time (with slight adjustments over the last year, possibly.) In these cases, an item is purchased in one month (January) and returned the following month (February, still within a 14-day or 30-day window). There aren't any other sales to that specific jurisdiction in the following month to fully cover the refund, or there are no sales to that particular jurisdiction. On our side, the transaction export is used to build the filing team's summary totals, but that summary is different; it's a state-specific sales tax internal report used to file the returns. I'm pulling data from the same source. This could also be occurring more often because we're adjusting for edited orders, voided transactions, and items that cause refunds across multiple jurisdictions. These are the Order IDs causing the negative amounts in local jurisdictions: #23832930 #23828180 #23837460 #23830180 #23834760 #23832720 #23836330 #23833050 #23822770 #23821470 #23830810 REF-6115898589436 #23835120 #23832520 #23837570 I hope this helps!

author: jason@shopravella.com
body: Hi Chris, Yes I'm surprised we had these come up again. I thought it would be just from January because of the higher amount of returns from December orders, combined with a seasonal drop off into January. We're definitely sure it's related to the negative amounts for specific jurisdictions right? Because I don't recall this happening at all last year, but now we've had 2 months with this issue. It seems either our transaction list export is missing something, or the filing team's calculation is being done differently this year. Form what I remember last year, the excel transaction list was usually more of an 'export' of the filing team's summary -- and so the numbers would generally match since it was from the same 'source'. Now it seems our transaction export and the filing team's summary totals are from a slightly different 'source', but with the 2 sources. Thanks, Jason

I'll approve the filings to get them moving along. Have a great week!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason, You're welcome! I hope you had a good weekend! After completing the investigation, I've found that all variances where the estimated tax due variance amount is above 5% are related to refunds causing negative amounts in local jurisdictions within a state. This is the primary cause for CA, CO, GA, and TN. This means that some refunds in the export I shared with you could not be accounted for because, according to the various states' rules (as noted during previous discussions/calls), we cannot file negative amounts in any state jurisdiction. For Texas, due to the low percent difference (~2.13%) and ruling out refunds in local jurisdictions as the cause, that difference is very likely related to rounding at the line item level (per transaction) when summing values for local jurisdictions. It's also possible that I'm unaware of other state-specific logic in place. I hope this is helpful. Do you know if we can proceed with the filings this month?

author: jason@shopravella.com

We are probably good to approve right away on Monday once the filing amounts (ie the email amounts) are not higher than your worksheet amounts - since it does seem your worksheet captures all the adjustments correctly; while the email amounts may be missing some of those adjustments. Have a great weekend, thanks !

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Jason and Bobbi, Another up date! We're still investigating this. I'm re-running some background processes and giving them extra time to complete in case there's something "stuck"/processing on the tax engine or database side. That said, a mix of the differences here could be due to refunds causing negative balances in local jurisdictions paired with state-specific rounding (e.g., IL and TN round to even dollar amounts on their filings). I may have another update tonight, but I hope to have this sorted out or confirmed by Monday. Our filing team is aware of the situation and noted that, as an exception, we'll still be able to file on Monday on time. Additionally, due to a recent improvement by our engineering team regarding time zones and transaction dates, I found a better way to export the data for the states we're filing for Ravella. An updated file is attached. Here's an overview: Have a good weekend!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi MJ, Following up regarding the tax-due estimate! We found a way to temporarily adjust to account for the order edit situation and other factors that could lead to your noted differences. We're still fine-tuning this method, but we have surfaced it for our engineering team to explore as a solution to force reconciliation between Zamp and Shopify. I've attached a file showing the tax amounts from Shopify and Zamp; this was used to determine the adjustments needed. We adjusted for the amounts by the difference noted in column F. The variance is slight enough to be related to time zones, rounding, and other state-specific causes; we share more details here . One essential point is that we discovered Shopify's US Sales Tax report does not include tax on shipping (' total_shipping_tax_amount ') in the ' total_item_tax_amount ' column. Shopify's reporting separately buckets shipping and item taxes; this article shares more details . This also means that the variance is a lower tax amount. As we discussed, we still plan to evaluate previous filing periods (including January 2025) and determine the best path forward for making those adjustments. This will start tomorrow and continue into next week. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body:
Hi Husain, You're welcome; thanks for the note regarding urgency here. I have some details to share below that may be helpful for you. Still, we're also escalating this internally to the folks who built this Adobe Commerce Extension for any confirmation or extra details. My findings so far: This event utilizes the Observer in Observer/AddUpdateTaxBlock.php and it can be found here . This Observer watches for specific events occurring with orders, invoices, credit memos, and areas where tax-related items could be displayed. That list is: {
    public const AFFECTED_LAYOUTS = [
        'sales_email_order_creditmemo_items',
        'sales_email_order_invoice_items',
        'sales_email_order_items',
        'sales_guest_creditmemo',
        'sales_guest_invoice',
        'sales_guest_print',
        'sales_guest_printcreditmemo',
        'sales_guest_printinvoice',
        'sales_guest_view',
        'sales_order_creditmemo',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_new',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_updateqty',
        'sales_order_creditmemo_view',
        'sales_order_invoice',
        'sales_order_invoice_new',
        'sales_order_invoice_updateqty',
        'sales_order_invoice_view',
        'sales_order_print',
        'sales_order_printcreditmemo',
        'sales_order_printinvoice',
        'sales_order_view'
    ]; The goal of this observer is to allow tax display customization, consistent tax presentation, and order process coverage (where tax rates are involved). If we hear otherwise or have any performance optimization feedback from our team, we'll follow up right away.

author: ryan@zamp.com
body: Hi Husain, The Adobe Commerce integration is an API integration; so it will simply use the account's API token. Based on the conversation we had with Michael and Gabe, they will use the same API token for both any on-premise implementation and Adobe Commerce. Just remember that the token provided by Becky is for a sandbox account and development purposes, but since the Adobe Commerce site is still under active development, it should be safe to use on their primary site until the live one becomes available. You can find the repository for the integration here: https://github.com/zamptax/zamptax-adobe-commerce-extension/ It's also available as of this week in the Adobe Commerce store: https://commercemarketplace.adobe.com/zamptax-module-zamp.html A full suite of documentation, as well as manual install if you so prefer, can be found here: https://support.zamp.com/category/78-adobe-commerce As always, please feel free to reach out if you need any assistance. author: becky@zamp.com
body: Hi Team, Here is an API token to test with. This account is a sandbox account dedicated to your company. [OneTimeSecret Link] - please note this will only allow you to view one time Here's the link to get into the test Zamp dashboard using this email - mjhaveri@squariongroup.com. You will need to create a password to set up your account. API Resources -- We have a wealth of documentation available at https://developer.zamp.com/ . If you or your team have any questions related to the API or any of the information in the documentation, guides, or sales tax questions, please feel free to reach us at support@zamp.com . Calculating States -- Zamp's API works by having logic that is directly associated with the account configurations that it's tied to. For example, you wouldn't receive calculations in states we don't have your company¬†registered in -- you'd get back "taxDue": 0.0 every time. To curve this to suit your early API adoption needs, we set up the following states for you. Also note that you should test all calls to the calculations endpoint with a date on or after 01/01/2024. This date represents the test accounts' "Nexus Start Date" for each state -- states you would want to calculate how much sales tax to collect for. On our initial onboarding call, we will configure your production account with all states you will need to calculate sales tax for, along with the associated "imposition" types. Imposition types determine the logic our API will use to apply the correct rate. The list of states below are ones that you should be receiving sales tax "taxDue" in, where the value is other than 0. Calculation states AZ CA IL NY TX Feel free to let us know if you or your team have any questions. Thanks,

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, Thanks for your patience here! We investigated this further and found that the difference is related to the three reasons, noted below. The reasons are: 17 SplitOrder transactions from September 2024 through December 2024 were not previously adjusted for and were brought into the February 2025 filing period to assist in recovering the tax for those transactions. This was for a total of -$59.11 . 19 SplitOrder transactions occurred on 2/1/2025 which were included in the January 2025 filing in February because Zamp adjusts for the state-specific timezone in our filings. These adjustments were brought into the February 2025 filing period to ensure the SplitOrders were accounted for. This was a total of -$57.28 . Depending on the state, the remaining difference is likely related to timezone adjustments of 2/28/2025 through 3/1/2025. This typically accounts for 1-2% of a variance between Zamp and Shopify with tax collected. This would account for the remaining $21.33 difference. I hope this helps. Please let us know if you have any questions!

author: chris@zamp.com
body: Hi Allison, A quick follow-up to the tax-due estimate. This month's filings for the February 2025 period include all Split Order adjustments like we handled in February for January. Additionally, this estimate and the February 2025 filing period includes all remaining Split Order adjustments for the September 2024 through December 2024 and Q4 2024 filing periods. Lastly, any Indiana 2024 Split Order adjustments with a date of 2/15/2025 are included, and these adjustments will be filed with your IN 2025 filing processed in 2026. Lastly, our engineering team is considering improvements to handle the differences created by the SplitOrder third-party Shopify app with Zamp's Shopify integration. We do not yet know if this is an improvement path that will be taken or when it will be released. Our engineering team is also considering different avenues of improvement that may improve this situation, without adjusting directly for the SplitOrder app. Until then, we will adjust for these split order situations each month before sending you a tax-due estimate. I hope that you're having a good week!

body: Good day, I'm trying to submit a transaction, and either I don't understand, or maybe the API's validation is off? Here is the payload: { "id": "33714404", "name": "CBI-202407-850", "transactedAt": "2024-07-09T11:00:00+00:00", "isResale": false, "discount": 989.9, "subtotal": 3960, "shippingHandling": 0, "total": 2970.1, "taxCollected": 0, "shipToAddress": { "line1": "210 Lomas Santa Fe Dr. - Ste. 500", "line2": null, "state": "CA", "city": "Solana Beach", "zip": "92075" }, "lineItems": [ { "id": "272948882", "amount": 0, "quantity": 1, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Hourly Training USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null }, { "id": "272948883", "amount": 3960, "quantity": 1, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Pineapple Academy Training Hour USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null }, { "id": "272948884", "amount": 0, "quantity": 100, "discount": 0, "shippingHandling": 0, "productName": "Training Monthly Active User USD Yearly", "productSku": null, "productTaxCode": null } ] } The error I get back is: [{\"code\":\"custom\",\"path\":[\"subtotal\"],\"message\":\"SUM(lineItem.subtotal) ‚àí transaction.discount = $2970.10 (not $3960.00)\"},{\"code\":\"custom\",\"path\":[\"total\"],\"message\":\"Subtotal + shipping + tax = $3960.00 (not $2970.10)\"}] Seems to me you have the total and subtotal validation flipped? If subtotal is supposed to be $2970.1... Then there is no way total would be $3960, else the discount is only applied on the subtotal? Thanks, Scott Pucket Chief Information Officer Pineapple Academy, Inc. 816.503.1569 pineappleacademy.com This electronic message transmission contains information from the Pineapple Academy which is privileged, confidential or otherwise the exclusive property of the sender or intended recipient.
